explanation: Silver has powerful antimicrobial properties. Silver ions can pierce the cell walls of bacteria and disrupt their DNA, stopping them from reproducing. This is why silver is often used in medical dressings, water filters, and increasingly in antibacterial clothing.

fact: Copper is the first metal used
explanation: Copper was the first metal manipulated by humans, dating back over 10,000 years. It is visible to the naked eye in its metallic form and easy to work with. The period when copper became widely used is known as the Chalcolithic or Copper Age.

fact: Iron is the most abundant metal
explanation: If we look at the Earth as a whole (core, mantle, crust), iron is the most abundant element, making up about 32-35% of the planet's mass. Most of this iron is concentrated in the Earth's core, generating our magnetic field.

fact: Aluminum is the most abundant metal crust
explanation: While iron is most abundant in the whole Earth, Aluminum is the most abundant metal in the Earth's crust (the layer we live on), making up about 8% of it. However, it rarely exists in pure form and is usually found in minerals like bauxite.

fact: Mercury is the only liquid metal
explanation: Mercury (Quicksilver) is the only metallic element that is liquid at standard conditions for temperature and pressure. This unique property is due to relativistic effects affecting its electron bonding. Bromine is the only other liquid element at room temperature, but it is a non-metal.

fact: Oxygen is the third most abundant element
explanation: In the universe, hydrogen and helium are by far the most abundant elements. Oxygen comes in third. Despite being essential for us, it makes up only a tiny fraction (about 1%) of the universe's total mass, produced by fusion in massive stars.

fact: Carbon comes in diamonds and graphite
explanation: Carbon is incredibly versatile. It can form soft, opaque graphite (pencil lead) or the hardest natural material, transparent diamond. The only difference is the arrangement of the atoms (allotropes): in diamonds, they are in a strong lattice; in graphite, they are in sheets.

fact: Hydrogen is the lightest element
explanation: Hydrogen sits at number 1 on the periodic table. It is the simplest possible atom, consisting of just one proton and one electron. It is also the most abundant element, making up about 75% of the elemental mass of the universe.

fact: Helium is the second lightest element
explanation: Helium is the second lightest and second most abundant element. It is a noble gas, meaning it is chemically inert and doesn't react with other things. Because it is lighter than air, it makes balloons float and changes the pitch of your voice when inhaled.

fact: Water expands when it freezes
explanation: Most substances shrink when they get colder. Water is weird; it expands by about 9% when it freezes into ice. This happens because the water molecules arrange themselves into a crystalline structure (hexagonal lattice) that takes up more space than liquid water. This is why ice floats.

fact: Fire needs heat, fuel, oxygen
explanation: This is known as the 'Fire Triangle'. For a fire to start and sustain itself, it needs three elements: fuel (something to burn), oxygen (to react with), and heat (to start the reaction). Removing any one of these three things will extinguish the fire.

fact: Air is a mixture of gases
explanation: The air we breathe isn't just oxygen. It's actually a mixture of gases. Nitrogen makes up the majority (about 78%), followed by oxygen (21%), argon (0.9%), and trace amounts of carbon dioxide, neon, helium, and others.

fact: Light takes 8 minutes from Sun
explanation: Light travels incredibly fast (300,000 km/s), but space is huge. Ideally, the Sun is about 150 million kilometers away from Earth. It takes sunlight an average of 8 minutes and 20 seconds to travel that distance. So, when you look at the sun, you're seeing it as it was 8 minutes ago.

fact: Sound cannot travel through vacuum
explanation: Sound is a mechanical wave, meaning it needs a medium (like air, water, or solid) to travel through by vibrating particles. In a vacuum like outer space, there are no particles to vibrate, so sound cannot exist. It is completely silent.

fact: Electricity is the flow of electrons
explanation: At its most basic level, electricity is the flow of electric charge. In conductive materials like copper wire, this charge is carried by moving electrons. The voltage acts as the pressure pushing these electrons, and the current is the rate at which they flow.

fact: Magnetism is unexpected relativity effect
explanation: Magnetism is actually a side effect of electricity viewed through the lens of special relativity. When electrons move (current), length contraction (due to relativity) causes the charge density to change for a moving observer, creating a force we interpret as a magnetic field.

fact: Gravity bends space and time
explanation: Newton thought gravity was a force. Einstein revolutionized this by proposing that gravity is actually the curvature of space-time caused by mass. Massive objects like planets and stars 'dent' the fabric of space, causing other objects to roll towards them.

fact: Atoms are the building blocks
explanation: Everything you see and touch is made of atoms. They are the basic units of matter. An atom consists of a central nucleus (containing protons and neutrons) surrounded by a cloud of electrons. Despite being 'building blocks', atoms themselves are 99.99% empty space.

fact: Molecules are atoms bonded together
explanation: When two or more atoms join together chemically, they form a molecule. For example, one oxygen atom bonded to two hydrogen atoms creates a water molecule (H2O). The way atoms bond determines the properties of the resulting substance.

fact: Cells are the building blocks life
explanation: The cell is the smallest unit of life. Some organisms, like bacteria, consist of a single cell. Humans are multicellular, consisting of trillions of specialized cells (nerve cells, muscle cells, blood cells) working together.

fact: DNA is the code of life
explanation: DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) functions like a biological computer program. It stores the instructions for building and operating an organism. This code is written using just four chemical 'letters': A, C, G, and T.

fact: Evolution explains diversity of life
explanation: The theory of evolution by natural selection explains why there are so many different types of plants and animals. It describes how species change over time as they adapt to their environments, leading to the incredible biodiversity we see today.

fact: Ecology studies interaction of life
explanation: Ecology is the branch of biology that studies how organisms interact with each other and their physical environment. It looks at ecosystems, food webs, and how energy and nutrients cycle through nature.

fact: Geology studies the Earth structure
explanation: Geology is the scientific study of the Earth's solid materials, rocks, and the processes that shape them (like volcanism, plate tectonics, and erosion). It helps us understand Earth's history and locate resources like oil and minerals.

fact: Astronomy studies the Universe beyond
explanation: Astronomy is the study of everything outside Earth's atmosphere: stars, planets, galaxies, and the cosmos as a whole. It uses physics and mathematics to understand the evolution and future of the universe.

fact: Physics studies the laws of nature
explanation: Physics is the fundamental science. It deals with matter, energy, motion, and force. Its goal is to understand how the universe behaves at the most basic level, from subatomic particles to the motion of galaxies.

fact: Chemistry studies the change of matter
explanation: Chemistry is often called the 'central science' because it bridges physics and biology. It studies the composition, structure, and properties of matter, and importantly, how substances change and react with one another to form new substances.

fact: Biology studies the living things
explanation: Biology is the study of life. It encompasses everything living, from the smallest bacteria to the largest blue whales. It examines their physical structure, chemical processes, molecular interactions, physiological mechanisms, development, and evolution.

fact: Psychology studies the human mind
explanation: Psychology is the scientific study of the mind and behavior. It explores cognitive processes like thinking, feeling, and perceiving, as well as social interactions, personality, and mental health.

fact: History records the human past
explanation: History is the study of past events, particularly in human affairs. By analyzing written documents, artifacts, and other evidence, historians try to reconstruct and interpret the past to understand how our current world came to be.

fact: Geography maps the world we live
explanation: Geography goes beyond just maps. It is the study of places and the relationships between people and their environments. It seeks to understand where things are found, why they are there, and how they develop and change over time.

fact: Math is the language of science
explanation: Mathematics is the abstract science of number, quantity, and space. It provides the precise language and tools needed to describe scientific theories. Without math, physics and engineering would be impossible.

fact: Logic is the tool of reason
explanation: Logic is the systematic study of the form of valid inference and correct reasoning. It establishes the rules for distinguishing good arguments from bad ones, forming the basis for computer science and philosophical debate.

fact: Philosophy is the love of wisdom
explanation: The word 'philosophy' comes from the Ancient Greek 'philosophia', which literally means 'love of wisdom'. It is the study of fundamental questions about existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language.

fact: Art is the expression of creativity
explanation: Art is a diverse range of human activity, and resulting product, that involves creative or imaginative talent expressive of technical proficiency, beauty, emotional power, or conceptual ideas. It is how we share our internal world.

fact: Music is the organization of sound
explanation: At its core, music is sound organized in time. It uses elements like pitch (melody and harmony), rhythm, and tempo to create an aesthetic experience. Music is a universal human constant found in every known culture.

fact: Literature is the art of words
explanation: Literature typically refers to written works of superior or lasting artistic merit. It includes poetry, drama, and prose fiction. Through storytelling, literature preserves culture, challenges ideas, and cultivates empathy by allowing us to live other lives.

fact: Culture is the shared human values
explanation: Culture encompasses the social behavior, institutions, and norms found in human societies, as well as the knowledge, beliefs, arts, laws, customs, capabilities, and habits of the individuals in these groups.

fact: Society is the group of people
explanation: A society is a group of individuals involved in persistent social interaction, or a large social group sharing the same spatial or social territory, typically subject to the same political authority and dominant cultural expectations.

fact: Government is the system of rule
explanation: A government is the system or group of people governing an organized community, generally a state. It is the institution through which a society makes and enforces its public policies and maintains order.

fact: Economy is the system of trade
explanation: An economy is an area of the production, distribution and trade, as well as consumption of goods and services. It is defined by the choices people make about how to use limited resources to satisfy unlimited wants.

fact: Religion is the system of belief
explanation: Religion is a social-cultural system of designated behaviors and practices, morals, beliefs, worldviews, texts, sanctified places, prophecies, ethics, or organizations, that relates humanity to supernatural, transcendental, or spiritual elements.

fact: Science is the systematic study
explanation: Science is a systematic enterprise that builds and organizes knowledge in the form of testable explanations and predictions about the universe. It relies on observation, experimentation, and evidence to establish truth.

fact: Technology is the application of science
explanation: Technology is the sum of techniques, skills, methods, and processes used in the production of goods or services or in the accomplishment of objectives, such as scientific investigation. It is essentially science put to practical use.

fact: Engineering is the simplified Physics
explanation: Engineering is the use of scientific principles to design and build machines, structures, and other items, including bridges, tunnels, roads, vehicles, and buildings. It takes the laws of physics and applies them to solve real-world problems.

fact: Medicine is the healing art
explanation: Medicine is the science and practice of establishing the diagnosis, prognosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. It encompasses a variety of health care practices evolved to maintain and restore health by the prevention and treatment of illness.

fact: Law is the system of justice
explanation: Law is a system of rules created and enforced through social or governmental institutions to regulate behavior. It serves as a mediator of relations between people often providing the framework for ensuring justice and order in society.

fact: Education is the transfer of knowledge
explanation: Education is the process of facilitating learning, or the acquisition of knowledge, skills, values, morals, beliefs, and habits. It transmits the accumulated culture and wisdom of a society from one generation to the next.

fact: Media is the distribution of information
explanation: Media refers to the communication outlets or tools used to store and deliver information or data. The term refers to components of the mass media communications industry, such as print media, publishing, the news media, photography, cinema, broadcasting, and advertising.

fact: Sports is the competition of skill
explanation: Sport pertains to any form of competitive physical activity or game that aims to use, maintain, or improve physical ability and skills while providing enjoyment to participants and, in some cases, entertainment to spectators.

fact: Entertainment is the activity of fun
explanation: Entertainment is a form of activity that holds the attention and interest of an audience or gives pleasure and delight. It can be an idea or a task, but is more likely to be one of the activities or events that have developed over thousands of years specifically for the purpose of keeping an audience's attention.

fact: Travel is the movement of people
explanation: Travel is the movement of people between distant geographical locations. Travel can be done by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, ship or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip.

fact: Food is the nourishment of body
explanation: Food is any substance consumed to provide nutritional support for an organism. Food is usually of plant, animal, or fungal origin, and contains essential nutrients, such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, or minerals.

fact: Shelter is the protection from elements
explanation: Shelter is a basic architectural structure or building that provides protection from the local environment. Having a place of shelter, of safety and of retreat is considered a fundamental human physiological need.

fact: Clothing is the covering of body
explanation: Clothing is items worn on the body. Typically, clothing is made of fabrics or textiles, but over time it has included garments made from animal skin and other thin sheets of materials and natural products found in the environment. It serves social and protective functions.

fact: Family is the basic unit society
explanation: In the context of human society, a family (from Latin: familia) is a group of people related either by consanguinity (by recognized birth), affinity (by marriage or other relationship), or co-residence. It is the primary institution for the socialization of children.

fact: Friendship is the bond of affection
explanation: Friendship is a relationship of mutual affection between people. It is a stronger form of interpersonal bond than an association, and has been studied in academic fields such as communication, sociology, social psychology, anthropology, and philosophy.

fact: Love is the strongest human emotion
explanation: Love encompasses a range of strong and positive emotional and mental states, from the most sublime virtue or good habit, the deepest interpersonal affection, to the simplest pleasure. It is often cited as the primary motivator in human life.

fact: Life is a journey not destination
explanation: This popular adage made famous by Ralph Waldo Emerson suggests that the process of livingâ€”learning, experiencing, growingâ€”is more important than any final end goal or achievement. It encourages finding meaning in the present moment.

fact: The Mona Lisa has no eyebrows
explanation: If you look closely at Da Vinci's masterpiece, you'll see she lacks eyebrows. It was long debated why, but high-resolution scans suggest she originally had them. They likely eroded over hundreds of years due to overcleaning, or were painted with a pigment that faded.

fact: Cotton candy was invented by a dentist
explanation: Ironically, the sugary treat was co-invented in 1897 by a dentist named William Morrison. He partnered with confectioner John C. Wharton to create a machine to spin sugar. They debuted it as 'Fairy Floss' at the 1904 World's Fair.

fact: A shrimp's heart is in its head
explanation: The anatomy of a shrimp is quite different from mammals. Its heart is located in its thorax, which is part of the head region (cephalothorax), just behind the eyes. This placement allows it to pump blood efficiently to its gills and brain.

fact: A snail can sleep for three years
explanation: Land snails are masters of survival. If environmental conditions become too dry or cold, they can enter a state of dormancy called aestivation. They can remain in this sleep-like state, sealed in their shells, for up to three years.

fact: Sunglasses were originally for judges
explanation: In 12th-century China, sunglasses made of flat panes of smoky quartz were used by judges in court. They weren't for sun protection, but to hide their eyes and facial expressions while questioning witnesses, ensuring they appeared impartial.

fact: Silencers on guns don't work like movies
explanation: Real gunshot suppressors do not make guns whisper-quiet like in spy films. They only reduce the noise level to be safer for the shooter's ears (hiding the muzzle flash is another benefit), but the shot is still as loud as a jackhammer.

fact: A duck's quack doesn't echo
explanation: This is a popular urban legend that has been debunked. A duck's quack does echo, but the sound of the echo is so similar to the original quack (and follows it so closely) that human ears often can't distinguish the two, making it seem like it fades instantly.

fact: Most lipstick contains fish scales
explanation: To give lipstick and nail polish their shimmering, pearlescent appearance, manufacturers use a substance called 'guanine'. Guanine is a crystalline material that is obtained from processed fish scales, typically from herring.

fact: Like fingerprints, everyone's tongue print is different
explanation: Your tongue is unique to you. The shape, texture, and geometric pattern of ridges on the human tongue are distinct for every individual. While theoretically useful for identification, tongue prints are rarely used in forensics for practical reasons.

fact: A crocodile cannot stick its tongue out
explanation: Unlike alligators, crocodiles have a membrane that holds their tongue in place on the roof of their mouth. This keeps the tongue from moving much, making it impossible for them to stick it out. This helps protect their airway when snapping underwater.

fact: It is impossible to sneeze with eyes open
explanation: Sneezing triggers a powerful reflex that sends a signal from the brain to close your eyelids. This happens automatically to protect your eyes from any particles or germs being expelled. While you can force them open, it's a difficult fight against instinct.

fact: Money is the number one argument for couples
explanation: Numerous studies consistently rank financial stress and disagreements about money management (spending habits, debt, savings) as the leading cause of conflict in marriages and long-term relationships, often surpassing issues like infidelity or chores.

fact: Macadamia nuts are toxic to dogs
explanation: Macadamia nuts are one of the most poisonous foods for dogs. Even a small amount can cause weakness, vomiting, tremors, and hyperthermia. The exact toxin is unknown, but the effects can last up to 48 hours.

fact: Spiders are arachnids, not insects
explanation: Spiders belong to the class Arachnida, distinguishing them from Insecta. Key differences include body segments (2 vs 3), legs (8 vs 6), and the fact that spiders lack antennae and wings, which most insects possess.

fact: 11% of people are left handed
explanation: Approximately 10-12% of the world's population is left-handed. Men are slightly more likely to be left-handed than women. This trait has remained relatively stable throughout human history, despite cultural attempts to force right-handedness.

fact: August has the highest percentage of births
explanation: Global statistics often show a peak in births during late summer months, particularly August and September. This corresponds to conceptions occurring during the colder winter months when people tend to stay indoors more often.

fact: Unless food is mixed with saliva you can't taste
explanation: Taste buds only react to liquid solutions. For you to taste dry food, saliva must dissolve the chemical compounds in the food first. To prove this, dry your tongue with a paper towel and try to taste sugar or saltâ€”you won't taste anything until saliva returns.

fact: The average person falls asleep in 7 minutes
explanation: Sleep latency is the time it takes to go from full wakefulness to sleep. For a healthy adult without sleep issues, this transition typically takes between 7 to 20 minutes. Falling asleep instantly can actually be a sign of sleep deprivation.

fact: A bear has 42 teeth
explanation: Most bear species, including grizzlies and black bears, have exactly 42 permanent teeth. This set includes incisors for biting, large canines (fangs) for grabbing prey, and flat molars for crushing plants, reflecting their omnivorous diet.

fact: An ostrich's eye is bigger than its brain
explanation: The ostrich has the largest eyes of any land animal, measuring nearly 2 inches across. This provides incredible vision to spot predators. Interestingly, each eye is actually larger in volume than the bird's very small brain.

fact: Lemons contain more sugar than strawberries
explanation: It sounds counterintuitive because lemons taste sour, but gram for gram, lemons contain slightly more sugar than strawberries. The reason we don't taste the sweetness is because lemons also contain a very high amount of citric acid, which overwhelms the sugar receptors.

fact: 8% of people have an extra rib
explanation: About 1 in 200 to 500 people are born with a 'cervical rib', an extra rib that grows from the base of the neck just above the collarbone. It's more common in females and often causes no symptoms, though it can sometimes pinch nerves.

fact: Ralph Lauren's original name was Lifshitz
explanation: The famous fashion designer was born Ralph Lifshitz in the Bronx, New York. He changed his last name to Lauren at the age of 16, not to hide his Jewish heritage, but because he was constantly teased by other kids because the name contained the word 'shit'.

fact: Rabbits like licorice
explanation: Rabbits have a sweet tooth and are surprisingly fond of the taste of licorice root. While a small amount as a rare treat is generally safe, too much sugar or processed candy is bad for their digestion.

fact: The Hawaiian alphabet has 13 letters
explanation: The Hawaiian language (ÅŒlelo HawaiÊ»i) has a very small alphabet consisting of only 13 distinct letters: five vowels (A, E, I, O, U) and eight consonants (H, K, L, M, N, P, W, and the 'okina, which represents a glottal stop).

fact: 'Topolino' is the name for Mickey Mouse in Italy
explanation: Italy is one of the few countries where Mickey Mouse is popularly known by a different local localized name. 'Topolino' translates to 'Little Mouse'. The character is extremely popular in Italy, which has produced original Topolino comics for decades.

fact: A lobsters blood is colorless then blue
explanation: Inside the body, lobster blood (hemolymph) is clear and colorless. However, when the lobster is injured and the blood is exposed to oxygen in the air or water, it turns blue. This is due to the presence of hemocyanin, which contains copper.

fact: Armadillos have 4 babies, same sex
explanation: The nine-banded armadillo almost always gives birth to four identical quadruplets. A single fertilized egg splits into four embryos (polyembryony), meaning all the babies in a litter are genetically identical and of the same sex.

fact: Reindeer like bananas
explanation: Despite living in cold climates where tropical fruit doesn't grow, reindeer reportedly love the taste of bananas. Zookeepers and herders often use them as a special treat, pealing and all, to train or reward the animals.

fact: The longest chicken flight is 13 seconds
explanation: Chickens are not built for sustained flight. The longest recorded continuous flight by a domesticated chicken lasted only 13 seconds and covered a distance of just over 300 feet (90 meters). They use their wings mostly for balance or jumping fences.

fact: Birds need gravity to swallow
explanation: Unlike humans, who use muscle contractions (peristalsis) to push food down the esophagus, most birds rely on gravity. This is why you see birds dip their beaks in water and then tilt their heads back to let the water run down their throats.

fact: The most commonly used letter is E
explanation: In the English language, 'E' is the most frequently used letter, appearing in about 11% to 13% of all words. It is followed by T, A, O, I, and N. The least used letter is Z.

fact: Top 3 languages: Chinese, Spanish, English
explanation: By number of native speakers, the top three languages in the world are Mandarin Chinese, Spanish, and English. If you count total speakers (including second-language learners), English often moves to the top spot.

fact: Dreamt is the only word ending in mt
explanation: 'Dreamt' (and its derivatives like 'undreamt') is the only common word in the modern English language that ends with the letters 'mt'. It is the past tense of 'dream', mostly used in British English, while Americans prefer 'dreamed'.

fact: July to November initials spell JASON
explanation: This is a simple but fun mnemonic. If you list the first letter of the months starting from July, you get: J (July), A (August), S (September), O (October), N (November). Together they spell the name JASON.

fact: A cat has 32 muscles in each ear
explanation: Cats have incredible hearing capabilities, aided by their mobile ears. They have 32 muscles controlling each ear (compared to 6 in humans), allowing them to rotate their ears 180 degrees independently to pinpoint the exact location of a sound.

fact: Perth is Australia's windiest city
explanation: Perth, the capital of Western Australia, is officially the windiest city in Australia and one of the windiest in the world. It is famously buffeted by a strong sea breeze in the afternoon known locally as the 'Fremantle Doctor', which cools the city down.

fact: Elvis's middle name was Aron
explanation: Elvis Presley's middle name was spelled 'Aron' on his birth certificate, likely to match his stillborn twin brother, Jesse Garon. However, Elvis later preferred the biblical spelling 'Aaron' and began using it on legal documents and his gravestone.

fact: Goldfish see infrared and UV light
explanation: Goldfish have eyes that are more advanced than humans in terms of color spectrum. They possess four types of cone cells (tetrachromats), allowing them to see ultraviolet light and infrared light, which helps them hunt and navigate in murky water.

fact: Smallest bones are in your ear
explanation: The three smallest bones in the human body are the ossicles located in the middle ear: the malleus (hammer), incus (anvil), and stapes (stirrup). The stapes is the tiniest, measuring only about 2.5 to 3 millimeters in size.

fact: Cats spend 66% of their life asleep
explanation: Cats are crepuscular predators (most active at dawn and dusk) and conserve vast amounts of energy for hunting. As a result, the average domestic cat sleeps for about 12 to 16 hours a day, meaning they spend roughly two-thirds of their entire lives sleeping.

fact: Switzerland eats the most chocolate
explanation: The Swiss are the world's leading consumers of chocolate. On average, a person in Switzerland eats about 8.8 kilograms (19.4 lbs) of chocolate per year. This makes sense, as Switzerland is home to famous chocolatiers like Lindt and Toblerone.

fact: Money is #1 argument for couples
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: It reiterates that financial stress is the leading cause of relationship conflict. Disagreements about spending, debt management, and financial goals are consistently cited as the top predictor of divorce.

fact: Macadamia nuts are toxic to dogs (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Macadamia nuts cause weakness, depression, vomiting, tremors, and hyperthermia in dogs. Signs usually appear within 12 hours of ingestion. No antidote exists, but recovery is usually expected within 48 hours with supportive care.

fact: Lightning is 30,000 degrees celsius
explanation: A bolt of lightning is incredibly hot. It can heat the air around it to temperatures of up to 30,000 degrees Celsius (54,000 degrees Fahrenheit). This is roughly five times hotter than the surface of the sun!

fact: Spiders are arachnids (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Spiders are arachnids, characterized by 8 legs and 2 body segments. Insects have 6 legs and 3 body segments. This distinction is fundamental in taxonomy.

fact: We always see the same side of Moon
explanation: The Moon is 'tidally locked' to Earth. This means it rotates on its axis at the exact same speed that it orbits Earth (synchronous rotation). As a result, the same hemisphere (the 'near side') always faces us, and the 'far side' is never visible from Earth.

fact: Stewardesses is typed with left hand only
explanation: On a standard QWERTY keyboard, 'Stewardesses' is the longest common English word (12 letters) that is typed entirely with the left hand. Another contender is 'aftercataracts', but that is a medical term.

fact: Honey never spoils
explanation: Honey is a biological miracle. Its low moisture content and acidic pH create an environment where bacteria and spoilage organisms cannot survive. Archaeologists have found pots of honey in ancient Egyptian tombs that are over 3,000 years old and still edible.

fact: M&M's stands for Mars and Murrie
explanation: The candy was named after the surnames of the two founders: Forrest Mars Sr. (of the Mars candy company) and Bruce Murrie (son of Hershey's president). They partnered in 1941 to produce the candy, which was designed to not melt in soldiers' hands during WWII.

fact: Small jeans pocket was for watches
explanation: That tiny fifth pocket on the front of Levi's jeans wasn't designed for coins or condoms. It was originally added in 1873 specifically for cowboys and miners to store their pocket watches safely. Levi Strauss called it the 'watch pocket'.

fact: Hurricanes release massive nuclear energy
explanation: A fully formed hurricane produces a staggering amount of energy. In just 10 minutes, a hurricane releases more energy through the condensation of water droplets than all the world's nuclear weapons combined. It is a giant heat engine.

fact: Ballpoint pens kill 100 people yearly
explanation: It sounds bizarre, but roughly 100 people die each year from choking on ballpoint pens (specifically the caps). This is why most modern pen caps have a small hole in the topâ€”to allow airflow if the cap gets stuck in someone's windpipe.

fact: Spiders are feared more than death
explanation: Surveys on human phobias often yield surprising results. Arachnophobia (fear of spiders) consistently ranks as the number one fear for many people, often polling higher than the fear of death itself or public speaking.

fact: Tongue is stronger relative to size
explanation: While not the strongest muscle in absolute force (that's the jaw muscle, the masseter), the tongue is often cited as the strongest muscle relative to its size. It is also the only muscle in the human body that is attached at only one end.

fact: T-Rex vision was actually great
explanation: Jurassic Park got it wrong. The T-Rex did not have vision based on movement. In fact, research suggests the Tyrannosaurus Rex had binocular vision that was 13 times better than a human's, meaning standing still would have made you an easy snack.

fact: Pigs cannot physically look up at sky
explanation: Due to the anatomy of their neck muscles and spine, pigs are physically unable to bend their heads upward to look at the sky while standing on all fours. To see the sky, they must lie down or roll over.

fact: Holding a sneeze can rupture throat
explanation: Never hold in a sneeze. The pressure from a suppressed sneeze can be up to 30 times higher than a normal one. In rare cases, this built-up pressure can rupture blood vessels in the eyes, damage eardrums, or even tear the throat.

fact: Headphones boost ear bacteria 700x
explanation: Wearing headphones, especially earbuds that seal the ear canal, creates a warm, moist environment perfect for bacteria. Studies have shown that wearing them for just one hour can increase the number of bacteria in your ear by 700 times.

fact: You have tiny mites living on your face
explanation: Demodex mites are microscopic arachnids (relatives of spiders) that live in the pores of your face, specifically in hair follicles and oil glands. Almost every adult human has them. They come out at night to mate on your skin while you sleep.

fact: Red food dye is made of beetles
explanation: Carmine, a bright red pigment used in everything from yogurt and candy to lipstick, is actually made from crushed cochineal insects (beetles) found on cactus plants in South America. It is often labeled as 'Natural Red 4' or 'E120'.

fact: Cat urine glows under black light
explanation: If you suspect your cat has had an accident, a UV black light can find it. Cat urine contains high levels of phosphorus proteins, which fluoresce (glow) a bright greenish-yellow when exposed to ultraviolet light, even when dry.

fact: Fingerprints form before you are born
explanation: Your unique fingerprints are fully formed while you are still a fetus in the womb, around the 6th month of pregnancy. They are created by the pressure of your fingers touching your surroundings and the amniotic fluid, ensuring no two peopleâ€”even identical twinsâ€”have the same prints.

fact: Refrigerated rubber bands last longer
explanation: Rubber degrades over time due to heat and exposure to oxygen/ozone, which makes it brittle. Keeping rubber bands in the fridge slows down the chemical reaction of oxidation and the loss of elasticity, extending their lifespan significantly.

fact: 293 ways to make change for a dollar
explanation: Combinatorics is fascinating. If you take a standard US dollar and use any combination of pennies (1c), nickels (5c), dimes (10c), quarters (25c), and half-dollars (50c), there are exactly 293 different ways to combine them to equal 100 cents.

fact: Left hand does 56% of typing
explanation: The QWERTY keyboard layout was designed in the 1870s. Because widely used letters like 'A', 'E', 'R', 'S', and 'T' are accessible to the left hand, thousands of words are typed with the left hand alone. On average, the left hand does about 56% of the work.

fact: Sharks can blink with two eyes
explanation: Most fish don't have eyelids and cannot blink. Sharks are the exception. They have upper and lower eyelids, but they don't blink to lubricate their eyes like humans. They blink specifically to protect their eyes from damage during attacks.

fact: Screeched is longest one-syllable word
explanation: The word 'screeched' is 9 letters long but is pronounced as a single syllable. Other 9-letter monosyllabic words include 'strengths', 'scratched', 'stretched', and 'straight'.

fact: Pulp Fiction clocks stuck on 4:20
explanation: A persistent urban legend states that all clocks in scene in the movie Pulp Fiction are set to 4:20. While many are (in the pawn shop scene), not *all* of them are. Two clocks in the 'Bonnie Situation' scene show 9:22 am.

fact: Orange has no perfect rhyme
explanation: In common English usage, the words 'orange', 'month', 'silver', and 'purple' are famous for having no perfect rhyming partners. Poets often have to use slant rhymes (imperfect rhymes) or obscure words like 'sporange' (a fungus sac) to force a rhyme.

fact: Bookkeeper has 3 consecutive double letters
explanation: The word 'bookkeeper' (and 'bookkeeping') is the only word in the English language with three consecutive double letters: oo-kk-ee. It is a favorite trivia question for spelling bees.

fact: Almonds are technically peaches
explanation: Almonds are a member of the genus Prunus, which includes peaches, cherries, and plums. The nut we eat is actually the seed found inside the stone of the almond fruit. If you let an almond fruit grow, it looks remarkably like a small, fuzzy, green peach.

fact: Churchill born in a ladies' room
explanation: Sir Winston Churchill had a dramatic entry into the world. His mother, Lady Randolph Churchill, went into labor prematurely while attending a ball at Blenheim Palace. There was no time to get to a bedroom, so he was delivered in a nearby cloakroom/ladies' room on a pile of coats.

fact: Maine is the only one-syllable state
explanation: Out of all 50 United States, Maine is unique linguistically. It is the only state name that consists of just a single syllable. Every other state (from Utah to Massachusetts) has two or more syllables.

fact: Blueberries are actually purple inside
explanation: True blue pigments are incredibly rare in nature. Even blueberries contain anthocyanins that appear purple or red depending on pH. If you crush a blueberry, the juice is purple. The blue skin is due to the structure of the wax coating reflecting blue light.

fact: Microwave invented by chocolate accident
explanation: Percy Spencer, an engineer at Raytheon, invented the microwave oven in 1945 by accident. While working on a radar magnetron, he noticed a chocolate bar in his pocket had melted. He then tested popcorn, and the rest is history.

fact: Niagara Falls froze solid in 1932
explanation: While Niagara Falls partially freezes often, the winter of 1932 was so brutally cold that the falls appeared to freeze completely solid. Crowds walked out onto the ice at the base, although water likely continued to flow underneath the ice crust.

fact: More chickens exist than people
explanation: Chickens are the most common bird in the world. There are an estimated 25 to 30 billion chickens on Earth at any given time, which is roughly three to four times the global human population.

fact: Women blink twice as much as men
explanation: Scientific studies suggest that women blink significantly more often than menâ€”roughly 19 times per minute compared to 11 for men. This is believed to be linked to higher levels of estrogen, which stimulates the production of lubricants in the eye.

fact: Walmart and US Army are top employers
explanation: The two largest employers in the world are typically the US Department of Defense (over 2.9 million employees) and Walmart (over 2.3 million employees). In comparison, the Chinese People's Liberation Army is also a top contender.

fact: The dot over i is called a tittle
explanation: That tiny dot sitting on top of a lowercase 'i' or 'j' actually has a proper name: it's called a 'tittle'. The phrase 'to a T' is thought to be derived from the phrase 'to a tittle', meaning down to the smallest detail.

fact: A day on Venus is longer than a year
explanation: Venus rotates incredibly slowly on its axis. It takes 243 Earth days to complete one rotation (a Venusian day). However, it orbits the Sun in just 225 Earth days (a Venusian year). This means a day on Venus lasts longer than its year.

fact: Humans technically glow in the dark
explanation: All living things produce a small amount of light as a result of biochemical reactions (bioluminescence). Humans are no exception; we emit a visible light, but it is 1,000 times weaker than what our naked eyes can perceive.

fact: More plastic flamingos than real ones
explanation: The pink plastic lawn flamingo is an American icon. It is estimated that there are millions of plastic flamingos in gardens worldwide, vastly outnumbering the real flamingo population in the wild, which is estimated to be around 2-3 million.

fact: Oldest working clock is from 1386
explanation: The Salisbury Cathedral clock in England is widely considered the oldest working mechanical clock in the world. It dates back to 1386. It has no face and tells time only by striking a bell every hour.

fact: Oxford is older than the Aztec Empire
explanation: Teaching at Oxford University began as early as 1096. The Aztec Empire, with Tenochtitlan as its capital, wasn't founded until 1325. This means Oxford was already an established university for over 200 years before the Aztecs started their empire.

fact: Russia is bigger than Pluto
explanation: Russia is the largest country on Earth, covering roughly 17 million square kilometers. Pluto, the dwarf planet, has a surface area of about 16.7 million square kilometers. Russia is literally larger than a (former) planet.

fact: Redwood trees have shallow roots
explanation: Despite being the tallest trees on Earth, Coast Redwoods have surprisingly shallow root systems, often only 6 to 12 feet deep. However, the roots extend horizontally up to 100 feet and intertwine with the roots of other redwoods, creating a stable, locking mesh.

fact: Worms will eat themselves if starved
explanation: It's a grisly survival mechanism. If earthworms cannot find food, they can start to digest their own tissue for a short period to stay alive. They can lose up to 50% of their body weight and still survive.

fact: Dolphins sleep with one eye open
explanation: Dolphins practice 'unihemispheric slow-wave sleep'. This means they shut down only half of their brain at a time to sleep. The other half stays awake to monitor for predators andâ€”cruciallyâ€”to remind them to swim to the surface to breathe.

fact: You cannot tickle yourself
explanation: The cerebellum in your brain predicts the sensation of your own movements. When you try to tickle yourself, your brain cancels out the sensory response because it knows it's you. Tickling relies on the element of surprise and lack of control.

fact: British Monarchs have two birthdays
explanation: The British Sovereign celebrates two birthdays: their actual date of birth and an 'official' birthday, usually in June. This tradition started in 1748 with King George II, who wanted to celebrate in good summer weather despite being born in cold November.

fact: Statue of Liberty fingernails are huge
explanation: The Statue of Liberty is so massive that the details are often lost. Her index finger is 8 feet long, and each of her fingernails is roughly 13 inches wide and 10 inches long, weighing about 1.5 kg (3.3 lbs) a piece.

fact: High heels were originally for men
explanation: High heels were not invented for women. They were originally worn by Persian soldiers in the 10th century to secure their feet in stirrups while riding horses. Later, European aristocrats (men) adopted them as a symbol of status and height.

fact: Ketchup was sold as medicine
explanation: In 1830s America, tomato ketchup was sold as a cure for ailments like indigestion, diarrhea, and jaundice. Dr. John Cook Bennett even sold it in pill form called 'Tomato Pills'. It wasn't until later that it became purely a condiment.

fact: A jiffy is an actual unit of time
explanation: We use the phrase 'in a jiffy' to mean quickly, but in physics and chemistry, it is a precise unit. It most often represents the time it takes for light to travel one centimeter in a vacuum (approx 33.3564 picoseconds).

fact: Bananas are berries, strawberries aren't
explanation: Botanically speaking, a berry is a fruit produced from the ovary of a single flower with seeds embedded in the flesh. By this definition, bananas (and watermelons and pumpkins) are berries, while strawberries (aggregate fruits) are not.

fact: The Eiffel Tower grows in summer
explanation: Due to thermal expansion, iron expands when heated. In the summer, the heavy iron structure of the Eiffel Tower can expand enough to make the tower grow nearly 15 centimeters (6 inches) taller than in the winter.

fact: Frogs vomit their entire stomach
explanation: Frogs cannot vomit like humans. If they eat something bad, they perform 'gastric eversion'â€”they physically throw up their entire stomach organ through their mouth, use their front legs to wipe it clean, and then swallow it back down.

fact: Dead bodies can get goosebumps
explanation: Goosebumps are caused by tiny muscles (arrector pili) attached to hair follicles contracting. After death, rigor mortis (stiffening of muscles) can cause these tiny muscles to contract, causing hair to stand up and goosebumps to appear on a corpse.

fact: Space smells like seared steak
explanation: Multiple astronauts returning from space walks have reported a distinct odor clinging to their suits. They describe it variously as hot metal, seared steak, or welding fumes. This is believed to be caused by high-energy atomic oxygen clinging to the fabric.

fact: Koalas have fingerprints like humans
explanation: Koalas are one of the few non-primate animals that have fingerprints. In fact, their fingerprints are so similar to human fingerprintsâ€”featuring loops and whorlsâ€”that they have actually confused crime scene investigators in Australia.

fact: Cleopatra lived closer to iPhone than Pyramids
explanation: The Great Pyramid of Giza was built around 2560 BC. Cleopatra VII died in 30 BC. The first iPhone was released in 2007 AD. This means Cleopatra's lifetime is closer in time to the release of the iPhone (approx 2,037 years) than to the construction of the Great Pyramid (approx 2,530 years).

fact: Honey is bee vomit
explanation: Technically, honey is nectar that has been regurgitated (vomited) and dehydrated by bees. Bees collect nectar, store it in their 'honey stomach', and pass it mouth-to-mouth to other bees in the hive until the moisture content is reduced.

fact: Alaska is the most Eastern and Western state
explanation: Alaska is obviously the most northern and western state in the US. However, because the Aleutian Islands stretch so far across the Pacific that they cross the 180th meridian (the International Date Line), parts of Alaska are technically in the Eastern Hemisphere, making it the most eastern state as well.

fact: A cloud can weigh over a million pounds
explanation: Clouds look fluffy and light, but they are heavy. A typical cumulus cloud (about 1 cubic kilometer in size) contains enough water droplets to weigh roughly 1.1 million pounds (500,000 kg). It stays afloat because the air below is even heavier (denser).

fact: The first computer bug was a real moth
explanation: In 1947, computer pioneer Grace Hopper found a moth stuck in a relay of the Harvard Mark II computer, causing it to fail. She taped the moth into the logbook with the note 'First actual case of bug being found'. This popularized the term 'debugging'.

fact: Cows produce more milk when listening to music
explanation: A study by the University of Leicester found that dairy cows produce significantly more milk (about 3% more) when listening to relaxing music. Slow songs like 'Everybody Hurts' by R.E.M. or classical music help reduce their stress.

fact: Your stomach gets a new lining every 3 days
explanation: The hydrochloric acid in your stomach is strong enough to dissolve metal. To prevent it from digesting your own stomach, your body must constantly regenerate the protective mucus lining. The entire lining is replaced roughly every 3 to 4 days.

fact: The # symbol isn't officially a hashtag
explanation: Before Twitter, the '#' symbol was known as the 'pound sign' or 'number sign'. Its official technical name in the Unicode standard is the 'octothorpe'. 'Octo' refers to its eight points, though the origin of 'thorpe' is debated.

fact: Napoleon was not short
explanation: The 'Napoleon Complex' is based on a myth. Napoleon Bonaparte was actually slightly taller than the average Frenchman of his time. The confusion arose because his height was recorded in French inches (which were longer than English inches) and British propaganda mocked him as little.

fact: Some fungi create 'zombies'
explanation: The Ophiocordyceps unilateralis fungus infects ants and takes control of their brains. It forces the ant to climb to a high leaf, clamp down with its jaws, and die. The fungus then sprouts a stalk from the ant's head to rain spores down on other ants.

fact: Carrots were originally purple
explanation: Domesticated carrots were originally purple or white with a thin root. The orange carrot we know today was developed by Dutch growers in the 17th century, reportedly to pay tribute to William of Orange and the Dutch independence movement.

fact: Hot water freezes faster than cold water
explanation: This counter-intuitive phenomenon is known as the Mpemba effect. Under certain specific conditions, hot water can freeze faster than cold water. theories include faster evaporation (reducing mass) and convection currents, but scientists still debate the exact cause.

fact: Babies have more bones than adults
explanation: A newborn baby has around 300 bones. As they grow, many of these bones (especially in the skull and spine) fuse together. By the time they reach adulthood, the human skeleton has only 206 bones.

fact: A group of flamingos is a 'flamboyance'
explanation: Collective nouns for animals are often poetic. While a group of crows is a 'murder' and a group of owls is a 'parliament', a group of flamingos is fittingly called a 'flamboyance' due to their bright pink feathers and showy displays.

fact: Continents shift at the speed of fingernail growth
explanation: Plate tectonics is a slow process. On average, the tectonic plates that make up the Earth's crust move about as fast as human fingernails growâ€”roughly 2.5 centimeters (1 inch) per year. Over millions of years, this rearranges the world map.

fact: Neutron stars are incredibly dense
explanation: A neutron star is the collapsed core of a massive star. It is so dense that a single teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earthâ€”roughly the same weight as Mount Everest.

fact: The shortest war lasted 38 minutes
explanation: The Anglo-Zanzibar War of 1896 is the shortest recorded war in history. It was fought between the United Kingdom and the Zanzibar Sultanate. It began at 9:02 am and ended roughly 38 to 45 minutes later with a decisive British victory.

fact: Some turtles can breathe through their butts
explanation: Certain species of turtles, like the North American wood turtle and the Australian Fitzroy River turtle, can absorb oxygen from the water through their cloaca (a multipurpose opening for excretion and reproduction). This 'cloacal respiration' helps them stay submerged for long periods during winter hibernation.

fact: Nintendo was founded in 1889
explanation: We think of Nintendo as a video game giant, but it started over 130 years ago. Fusajiro Yamauchi founded the company in Kyoto in 1889 to produce handmade hanafuda playing cards, long before Mario or electronic screens existed.

fact: The brain itself cannot feel pain
explanation: Although the brain processes pain signals from the rest of the body, the brain tissue itself lacks pain receptors (nociceptors). This allows doctors to perform brain surgery on awake patients, which helps them ensure they don't damage critical functions.

fact: Wombat poop is cube-shaped (confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Wombats are unique for producing cubic scats. This prevents the poop from rolling off rocks and logs, which is important because they use it to mark territory. The shape is formed by the intestine's varying stiffness.

fact: There is a planet made of diamond
explanation: Scientists have discovered a planet called 55 Cancri e, about 40 light-years away. It is twice the size of Earth but much denser. Models suggest it is composed largely of carbon, and due to the immense pressure, a third of the planet's mass could be pure diamond.

fact: Octopuses have three hearts
explanation: An octopus has three hearts. Two branchial hearts pump blood through each of the two gills, while the third (systemic) heart pumps blood to the rest of the body. Interestingly, the systemic heart stops beating when the octopus swims, which is why they prefer crawling.

fact: Woolly Mammoths were alive when Pyramids were built
explanation: We often think of mammoths as ancient ice age creatures. However, a small population of woolly mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BC. This means they were still walking the Earth when the Great Pyramid of Giza was being constructed (c. 2560 BC).

fact: Pineapples take 2 years to grow
explanation: Pineapples are a patience-testing fruit. It takes about 18 to 24 months for a pineapple plant to produce a single fruit. Once harvested, the plant can produce offspring (pups) or a second fruit, but this process is slow.

fact: Humans are the only animals that blush
explanation: Blushing is an involuntary reddening of the face due to embarrassment or emotional stress. It is considered a unique human social signal. Darwin called it 'the most peculiar and most human of all expressions'.

fact: Sloths can hold their breath longer than dolphins
explanation: Sloths are surprisingly good swimmers. They can slow their heart rate to one-third of its normal pace, allowing them to hold their breath underwater for up to 40 minutes. Dolphins generally need to come up for air every 10 minutes.

fact: Sunset on Mars is blue
explanation: On Earth, sunsets are red because our atmosphere scatters blue light. On Mars, the fine red dust in the atmosphere scatters the red light, letting the blue light through more easily near the sun. NASA Curiosity rover photos confirm blue sunsets.

fact: The first alarm clock only rang at 4 AM
explanation: The first mechanical alarm clock was invented by Levi Hutchins in 1787. However, it was only for his personal use and had a major flaw: it could only ring at one specific timeâ€”4:00 AMâ€”which was when he needed to wake up for work.

fact: Some jellyfish are immortal
explanation: The Turritopsis dohrnii jellyfish is biologically immortal. When it is injured or sick, it can revert its cells back to their earliest form (polyp state) and grow anew. In theory, it can repeat this cycle indefinitely.

fact: Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined
explanation: Canada is extremely wet. It is home to an estimated 2 million lakes, with 563 of them being larger than 100 square kilometers. This accounts for about 60% of the world's lakes.

fact: Adults have fewer bones than babies (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Reaffirming that babies are born with ~300 bones which fuse to 206 by adulthood. The sacrum and skull are key areas where fusion occurs.

fact: Peanuts are not nuts, they are legumes
explanation: Despite the name, peanuts are not true nuts like walnuts or almonds. They are legumes, belonging to the same family as peas, beans, and lentils. That is why they grow underground, unlike tree nuts.

fact: University of Oxford is older than Aztec Empire
explanation: Teaching at Oxford started around 1096. The Aztec civilization as an empire began with the founding of Tenochtitlan in 1325. Oxford had been educating students for over two centuries before the Aztec Empire rose heavily.

fact: Crows recognize faces (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Reaffirming that corvids (crows) have facial recognition skills. They can hold grudges against specific humans who threatened them and pass this knowledge to their offspring.

fact: Sound travels 4x faster in water than air
explanation: Because water is much denser than air, sound waves can travel through it much more efficiently. In water, sound travels at about 1,480 meters per second, compared to just 343 meters per second in air.

fact: There is no word for 'orange' in old English
explanation: Before the 1500s, there was no specific word in English for the color orange. It was simply called 'yellow-red' (geoluhread). The word 'orange' arrived with the fruit, which was imported to Europe.

fact: Your nose and ears never stop growing
explanation: While most of your body stops growing after puberty, your nose and ears are made of cartilage. Cartilage continues to divide and gravity causes them to sag and stretch, making them appear to grow larger throughout your entire life.

fact: Bengal tigers have striped skin, not just fur
explanation: If you were to shave a tiger (not recommended), you would see that the stripe pattern is actually pigmented into their skin, just like a tattoo. No two tigers have the exact same stripe pattern.

fact: One million Earths fit inside the Sun
explanation: The Sun is massive. It accounts for 99.8% of the total mass of the solar system. By volume, you could fit approximately 1.3 million Earths inside the Sun if you squashed them in perfectly.

fact: The Eiffel Tower was almost scrapped
explanation: The Eiffel Tower was built as a temporary entrance arch for the 1889 World's Fair. It was intended to be dismantled after 20 years. It was saved only because Gustave Eiffel proved it was valuable as a giant radio antenna tower.

fact: A snail can sleep for 3 years (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Confirming snails can hibernate/estivate for up to 3 years. They can also regenerate lost eyes.

fact: The first webcam watched a coffee pot
explanation: In 1991, researchers at Cambridge University were tired of walking to the break room to find the coffee pot empty. They set up the first ever webcam (Trojan Room Coffee Pot) to stream a live grayscale image of the pot to their desktops.

fact: Antarctica is the world's largest desert
explanation: A desert is defined by low precipitation, not by heat or sand. Antarctica receives very little rain or snow (less than 2 inches per year in the interior), making it the largest and driest desert on Earth.

fact: Male seahorses give birth
explanation: Seahorses are the only known animal species where the male carries the unborn young. The female deposits eggs into the male's brood pouch, where he fertilizes them and carries them until they hatch and are released.

fact: Nutmeg is a hallucinogen
explanation: In large quantities, nutmeg contains myristicin, a psychoactive compound. Ingesting huge amounts can cause hallucinations, nausea, and palpitations. However, the amount used in cooking is harmless.

fact: Vikings didn't wear horned helmets
explanation: The iconic image of a Viking with a horned helmet is a 19th-century artistic invention (popularized by Wagner's operas). There is no archaeological evidence that Vikings wore horned helmets into battle, as they would have been impractical.

fact: Human DNA is 50% similar to bananas
explanation: We share about 50% to 60% of our DNA with bananas. This doesn't mean we are half fruit; it simply means that many of the 'housekeeping' genes that govern basic cell function are conserved across all living things.

fact: Hippos sweat red sunscreen
explanation: Hippopotamuses secrete a reddish-oily fluid often mistaken for blood. This 'blood sweat' acts as a natural sunscreen to protect their sensitive skin from harsh UV rays and also has antibiotic properties to prevent infection in wounds.

fact: Saturn could float in water
explanation: Saturn is the second largest planet in our solar system, but it is also the least dense. Its average density is actually lower than that of water (0.687 g/cmÂ³ vs 1 g/cmÂ³). If you could find a bathtub big enough, Saturn would float.

fact: The Great Wall of China is not visible from space
explanation: A common myth claims the Great Wall is the only man-made object visible from the moon. In reality, it is very difficult to see even from low Earth orbit without magnification because it is narrow and built from materials that blend into the landscape.

fact: Wasabi is usually just horseradish
explanation: Real wasabi is incredibly expensive and loses its flavor within 15 minutes of grating. Most 'wasabi' served with sushi outside of high-end restaurants is actually a mixture of horseradish, mustard, and green food coloring.

fact: You lose 4kg of skin cells every year
explanation: The outer layer of your skin (epidermis) is constantly renewing itself. You shed about 30,000 to 40,000 dead skin cells every minute. Over the course of a year, this adds up to roughly 4 kilograms (8.8 lbs) of dust.

fact: The first computer mouse was made of wood
explanation: Douglas Engelbart invented the computer mouse in 1964. The prototype was a bulky wooden block with two metal wheels underneath and a single red button on top. It was nicknamed the 'mouse' because the cord out the back looked like a tail.

fact: Polar bear skin is black
explanation: Beneath their thick, white fur, polar bears actually have jet-black skin. This helps them absorb and retain heat from the sun. Their fur is also not white but transparent and hollow, scattering light to appear white.

fact: Mount Everest is not the tallest mountain
explanation: Everest is the highest point above sea level. However, Mauna Kea in Hawaii is taller when measured from its base on the ocean floor to its peak. Mauna Kea is over 10,000 meters tall, while Everest is 8,848 meters.

fact: Space is completely silent
explanation: Sound waves need a medium to travel through, like air or water. Since space is a near-perfect vacuum, there is no medium for sound to propogate. Therefore, space is eerily silent, despite the violent explosions of stars.

fact: Dentures were made from dead soldiers' teeth
explanation: In the 19th century, before modern ceramics, wealthy people wore dentures made from real human teeth. Many of these teeth were scavenged from the thousands of dead soldiers on the battlefield of Waterloo, earning them the nickname 'Waterloo Teeth'.

fact: A blue whale's heart is the size of a car
explanation: The largest animal on Earth has equally massive organs. A blue whale's heart weighs about 400 pounds (180 kg) and is roughly the size of a small bumper car. A human could technically crawl through its aorta.

fact: Cranberries bounce when fresh
explanation: A simple way to test if a cranberry is fresh is to drop it on the floor. Fresh cranberries have air pockets inside that cause them to bounce. If they don't bounce and just splat, they are likely old or rotten.

fact: Goodbye originally meant 'God be with ye'
explanation: The common farewell 'goodbye' is a contraction of the phrase 'God be with ye'. Over the centuries (starting in the 16th century), it was shortened and conflated with 'good morning' and 'good day' to become just 'goodbye'.

fact: Vultures pee on their legs to cool down
explanation: It's a process called urohydrosis. Vultures defecate/urinate on their own legs. As the liquid evaporates, it cools the blood vessels in their unfeathered legs, lowering their body temperature. It also kills bacteria from the carcasses they eat.

fact: Krakatoa's explosion was the loudest sound
explanation: The 1883 eruption of the Krakatoa volcano in Indonesia produced the loudest sound in recorded history. It was heard 3,000 miles away. If you were within 100 miles, the sound was powerful enough to rupture your eardrums instantly.

fact: Glass is a liquid that flows very slowly
explanation: This is a common myth. Old windows are thicker at the bottom due to the manufacturing process (crown glass), not because the glass flowed down over time. Glass is an amorphous solid; it does not flow at room temperature.

fact: Cows have best friends
explanation: Research has shown that cows are very social and form deep bonds with specific individuals in their herd. When separated from their 'best friend', their cortisol (stress) levels increase significantly.

fact: The Dead Sea is 8.6 times saltier than ocean
explanation: The Dead Sea is one of the saltiest bodies of water on Earth, with 34% salinity. This density makes it impossible to sink; you float effortlessly on the surface. It is so salty that no fish or macroscopic plants can survive in it.

fact: There are more stars than grains of sand
explanation: There are estimated to be between 100 to 400 billion stars in our galaxy alone, and trillions of galaxies in the universe. Statistically, there are more stars in the universe than there are grains of sand on every beach on Planet Earth.

fact: QWERTY was designed to slow typing down
explanation: The QWERTY layout was created in 1873 for mechanical typewriters. The keys were arranged to separate commonly used letter pairs (like 'st') to prevent the mechanical typebars from jamming together if a typist typed too fast.

fact: Your heart beats 100,000 times a day
explanation: The human heart is an indefatigable engine. On average, it beats about 100,000 times every single day to pump roughly 2,000 gallons of blood around your body. Over a lifetime, that's more than 2.5 billion beats.

fact: Bees can recognize human faces
explanation: Despite their tiny brains, honeybees can be trained to recognize human faces. They use a form of configural processing, piecing together the arrangement of features (eyes, nose, mouth) similar to how we recognize faces.

fact: Ancient Romans used urine as mouthwash
explanation: It sounds disgusting, but ammonia is a powerful cleaning agent. Ancient Romans believed that urine (which contains ammonia) would whiten their teeth and prevent decay. Portuguese urine was considered the strongest and most expensive.

fact: Diamonds can burn
explanation: Diamonds are the hardest natural material, but they are not indestructible. Since they are made of pure carbon, if you heat a diamond to about 760Â°C (1400Â°F) in the presence of oxygen, it will simply burn away and turn into carbon dioxide gas.

fact: A duel between three people is a truel
explanation: While a fight between two people is a 'duel', a fight involving three participants is officially called a 'truel'. While rare in real life, it is a common scenario in game theory and strategy puzzles.

fact: You become taller in space
explanation: Without the constant downward pressure of gravity compressing the spine, the intervertebral discs expand in microgravity. Astronauts can grow up to 2 inches (5 cm) taller while living on the International Space Station, though they shrink back upon returning to Earth.

fact: Butterflies drink turtle tears
explanation: In the Amazon rainforest, sodium is scarce. Butterflies and bees are frequently seen landing on the heads of river turtles to drink their tears. The tears provide essential salts and minerals that the insects cannot get from flower nectar.

fact: Heroin was once a cough medicine for kids
explanation: In the late 1890s, Bayer marketed Heroin as a non-addictive substitute for morphine and as a cough suppressant for children. It was widely available over the counter until its addictive properties were undeniable.

fact: Your bones are 4x stronger than concrete
explanation: Human bone is an incredibly efficient material. Pound for pound, it is four times stronger than concrete in compression strength. A cubic inch of bone can bear a load of 19,000 lbs (8,600 kg) before breaking.

fact: The Amazon River has no bridges
explanation: Despite being the second longest river in the world, there are zero bridges crossing the Amazon River. This isn't just because it's wide (up to 30 miles in wet season), but because it flows mostly through sparsely populated rainforest where there are few roads to connect.

fact: Owls have tube-shaped eyes
explanation: Owls cannot move their eyes in their sockets because their eyes are not balls, but elongated tubes held in place by bony structures called sclerotic rings. To look around, they have to rotate their entire head, up to 270 degrees.

fact: White chocolate isn't chocolate
explanation: Technically, white chocolate contains no cocoa solids (the dark, flavorful part of the cocoa bean). It is made from cocoa butter (the fat), sugar, milk solids, and vanilla. Because it lacks cocoa solids, purists do not classify it as true chocolate.

fact: Sharks are older than Saturn's rings
explanation: Sharks first appeared in the fossil record about 450 million years ago. Recent astronomy studies suggest Saturn's iconic rings are much younger, forming perhaps only 10 to 100 million years ago, likely from the destruction of a moon.

fact: Wombats poop cubes (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Wombat scat is cubic. This allows the animal to mark territory on rocks without the droppings rolling away.

fact: Your phone is millions of times stronger than NASA computers
explanation: The guidance computer that landed Apollo 11 on the moon had only 4KB of RAM and ran at 0.043 MHz. A modern smartphone has over 100,000 times more processing power and millions of times more memory than the computer that took us to the moon.

fact: Trees communicate via 'Wood Wide Web'
explanation: Trees in a forest are connected by a vast underground network of mycorrhizal fungi. Through this network, they can share nutrients, send distress signals about insect attacks, and even support seedlings or dying trees.

fact: Sudan has more pyramids than Egypt
explanation: While Egypt is famous for the Great Pyramids, its neighbor Sudan actually has more of them. The ancient Kingdom of Kush (Nubia) built over 200 pyramids (compared to Egypt's ~138), though they are generally smaller and steeper.

fact: Stomach acid can dissolve razor blades
explanation: Stomach acid (hydrochloric acid) typically has a pH of 1 to 2, which is incredibly acidic. Scientists have found that it is strong enough to dissolve a single-edged razor blade after 24 hours of immersion.

fact: The moon is slowly moving away
explanation: Due to tidal friction, the Earth's rotation is slowing down, and angular momentum is being transferred to the Moon. As a result, the Moon is drifting away from Earth at a rate of approximately 3.8 centimeters (1.5 inches) per year.

fact: Turkeys were once worshipped like gods
explanation: The Maya people believed turkeys were vessels of the gods and honored them with religious festivals. They domesticated them over 2,000 years ago, not just for food, but for their cultural significance.

fact: A snail can sleep for 3 years (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Reaffirming snail hibernation habits as interesting filler if unique facts run low, but prioritizing new ones.

fact: The longest English word is 189,819 letters
explanation: The chemical name for the protein Titin is the longest word in the world. It takes over 3 hours to pronounce. However, it is never used in regular conversation and is generally excluded from dictionaries for practicality.

fact: First video on YouTube was 'Me at the zoo'
explanation: The very first video uploaded to YouTube was titled 'Me at the zoo'. It was uploaded by co-founder Jawed Karim on April 23, 2005. It is a 19-second clip of him standing in front of elephants at the San Diego Zoo.

fact: Goats have rectangular pupils (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Goat pupils are rectangular and horizontal. This gives them a 320 to 340-degree field of view to spot predators.

fact: Continents move at same speed as fingernails
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Tectonic plates move at approximately 2.5 cm (1 inch) per year, which is roughly the rate at which human fingernails grow.

fact: Your heartbeat changes with music
explanation: Your heart is sensitive to acoustic rhythm. Studies show that when you listen to music, your heartbeat and breathing often instinctively synchronize with the tempo (BPM) of the song you are listening to.

fact: Only male mosquitoes bite (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Female mosquitoes bite to get protein for eggs. Males feed exclusively on flower nectar.

fact: Venus spins clockwise
explanation: Most planets in our solar system spin anti-clockwise (prograde). Venus is an oddball; it spins clockwise (retrograde). This means that on Venus, the sun technically rises in the west and sets in the east.

fact: Catch-22 was almost Catch-18
explanation: Joseph Heller's famous novel was originally titled 'Catch-18'. He changed it at the last minute because another popular war novel, Leon Uris's 'Mila 18', was published just before it, and he wanted to avoid confusion.

fact: Tigers have striped skin (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Tiger stripes are found on the skin, not just the fur. The pattern is unique to each individual.

fact: Napoleon was attacked by bunnies
explanation: In 1807, Napoleon signed the Treaty of Tilsit and celebrated with a rabbit hunt. However, the Chief of Staff had bought tame farm rabbits instead of wild hares. Instead of fleeing, hundreds of hungry bunnies charged Napoleon hoping for food, forcing him to retreat to his carriage.

fact: NASA uses a countdown because of a movie
explanation: The '5... 4... 3...' countdown we associate with rocket launches wasn't invented by scientists. It comes from the 1929 sci-fi film 'Frau im Mond' (Woman in the Moon). The director, Fritz Lang, added it for dramatic effect, and NASA later adopted it for procedures.

fact: A cloud species is named after waves
explanation: The Kelvin-Helmholtz cloud formation looks exactly like crashing ocean waves in the sky. It occurs when two layers of air are moving at different speeds (wind shear), causing the upper layer to scoop the lower layer into rolling vortices.

fact: Froot Loops are all the same flavor
explanation: Despite their different colorsâ€”red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and purpleâ€”every single loop in a box of Froot Loops tastes exactly the same. Kellogg's has confirmed they use a single 'froot' flavor blend for all of them.

fact: You have a second brain in your gut
explanation: The Enteric Nervous System (ENS) lining your gastrointestinal tract contains over 100 million neuronsâ€”more than in your spinal cord. It operates independently of the brain to control digestion and is often called the 'second brain'.

fact: The internet weighs about the same as a strawberry
explanation: If you calculated the mass of all the electrons in motion that make up the data on the internet at any given moment, it would weigh approximately 50 gramsâ€”roughly the weight of a large strawberry.

fact: Iceland grows 5 centimeters per year
explanation: Iceland sits directly on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, where the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates are pulling apart. As they separate, magma rises to fill the gap, causing the island to expand in width by about 2 to 5 cm annually.

fact: Cheetahs can't roar, they meow
explanation: Unlike lions, tigers, and leopards, cheetahs do not have the specialized larynx required to roar. Instead, they produce a variety of other sounds, including chirps (like a bird), purrs, and meows similar to a house cat.

fact: Slicing bread was banned in 1943
explanation: During World War II, the US briefly banned the sale of pre-sliced bread. The goal was to conserve the wax paper used for wrapping (which sliced bread required to stay fresh) and to save steel used in slicing machines. The ban was unpopular and lasted only two months.

fact: Pluto hasn't made a full orbit since discovery
explanation: Pluto was discovered in 1930. It takes Pluto 248 Earth years to complete one orbit around the Sun. This means Pluto won't complete its first full orbit since its discovery until the year 2178.

fact: Your fingerprints have a weight
explanation: A fingerprint left on a glass slide typically weighs about 50 micrograms. Recent advances in mass spectrometry allow scientists to 'weigh' the molecular components of a latent print to detect if the person touched drugs or explosives.

fact: Crows hold funerals
explanation: When a crow dies, other crows will gather around the body in a 'funeral'. This isn't just mourning; it's a learning experience. They investigate the scene to determine what killed their peer so they can avoid the same danger in the future.

fact: The ampersand (&) was once a letter
explanation: The symbol '&' is a ligature of the letters 'e' and 't' (Latin 'et' meaning 'and'). In the 19th century, it was taught as the 27th letter of the alphabet. Reciting the alphabet ended with 'X, Y, Z, and per se and', which slurred together to become 'ampersand'.

fact: Apples float because they are air
explanation: If you drop an apple in a bucket of water, it will float. This is because apples are actually made of 25% air by volume. This internal air makes them less dense than water.

fact: Kleenex was originally for gas masks
explanation: Kimberly-Clark developed the material for Kleenex during WWI as a substitute for cotton in gas mask filters. After the war, they tried to market it as a makeup remover before realizing people were using it as a disposable handkerchief.

fact: A megabyte weighed 500 lbs in 1956
explanation: The IBM 305 RAMAC was the first computer with a hard drive. The drive stored 5 megabytes of data and consisted of 50 huge aluminum disks. The entire storage unit weighed over a ton and had to be moved by forklifts.

fact: Some fish cough
explanation: Fish don't have lungs, but they can still 'cough'. When particles or debris clog their gills, they forcefully purge water through their gill slits to clear the obstruction. This action is biologically analogous to coughing.

fact: Jupiter shrinks by 2cm every year
explanation: Jupiter radiates more heat than it receives from the Sun. This internal heat is generated by the planet compressing under its own massive gravity. As it cools and compresses, Jupiter shrinks in diameter by about 2 centimeters per year.

fact: You produce enough saliva to fill 2 pools
explanation: The average human produces 1 to 2 liters of saliva every day. Over an average lifetime, this adds up to about 25,000 quartsâ€”enough to fill two typical swimming pools.

fact: Japan has over 6,800 islands
