explanation: Japan is an archipelago, but most people only know the four main islands (Honshu, Hokkaido, Kyushu, and Shikoku). However, the country actually consists of 6,852 islands, of which only about 430 are inhabited.

fact: There were active volcanoes on the moon
explanation: The dark patches on the Moon (maria) are ancient lava flows. However, NASA's Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter found evidence that volcanic activity occurred on the Moon as recently as 100 million years ago, when dinosaurs roamed the Earth.

fact: Cows have accents
explanation: Dairy farmers have long suspected it, and phonetic specialists have confirmed it: cows moo with distinct accents depending on the region they live in, much like humans. A cow from Somerset sounds different from a cow in the Midlands.

fact: A single lightning bolt can toast 100,000 slices of bread
explanation: A typical lightning bolt contains about 1 billion joules of energy. Since toasting a slice of bread takes about 10,000 joules, one stroke of lightning contains enough energy to toast 100,000 slices of bread instantly.

fact: The word 'girl' used to mean a child
explanation: In the Middle Ages (around 1300), the English word 'girl' meant a child or young person of either sex. A male child was a 'knave girl' and a female child was a 'gay girl'. It wasn't until the 1500s that the meaning narrowed to female.

fact: Honey never spoils
explanation: Archaeologists have found pots of honey in ancient Egyptian tombs that are over 3,000 years old and still perfectly edible. Its low moisture content and acidic pH create an environment where bacteria and spoilage organisms cannot survive.

fact: Android was originally for cameras
explanation: Before Google bought it, Android was a startup building an operating system for digital cameras. They pivoted to mobile phones only after realizing that the standalone camera market was shrinking while the smartphone market was about to explode.

fact: Koalas fingerprints are like humans (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Reaffirming that simple loops and whorls on koala fingers are nearly indistinguishable from humans, even under a microscope.

fact: Albert Einstein could have been President of Israel
explanation: In 1952, after the death of Israel's first president, Chaim Weizmann, the Israeli government offered the presidency to Albert Einstein. Einstein politely declined, stating that he lacked the 'natural aptitude and the experience to deal properly with people'.

fact: Uranus spins on its side
explanation: Most planets spin like a top with a slight tilt. Uranus is unique; it is tilted at 98 degrees, meaning it essentially rolls around the Sun on its side like a bowling ball. This causes extreme seasons that last for 21 years.

fact: Your hair contains gold
explanation: Human hair naturally contains traces of gold. However, don't get excited about mining it. The average concentration is incredibly low, and even if you harvested all the hair from 100,000 people, you likely wouldn't even get a gram of gold.

fact: There is a town called 'A'
explanation: In Norway, there is a village named simply 'Ã…'. In Scandinavian languages, 'Ã…' means 'stream' or 'river'. It is a popular tourist destination, in part because people keep stealing the road signs for souvenirs.

fact: Dragonflies have nearly 360-degree vision
explanation: Dragonflies have massive compound eyes that cover almost their entire head. Each eye contains up to 30,000 lenses (ommatidia). They can see in almost every direction at once, with only a tiny blind spot directly behind them.

fact: Ripe cranberries bounce (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Reaffirming the 'bounce test' for cranberries. Farmers literally use wooden barrier boards to separate good bouncing berries from bad ones.

fact: Mammoths built the pyramids (Myth debunked)
explanation: A common misconception is that mammoths helped build the pyramids. While mammoths were alive when the pyramids were built, they lived in the Arctic (Wrangel Island), thousands of miles away from Egypt. Egyptians used manpower, not mammoths.

fact: Email is older than the World Wide Web
explanation: The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971 on the ARPANET. The World Wide Web (websites, HTTP) wasn't invented by Tim Berners-Lee until 1989. So, we were sending emails almost two decades before we were browsing websites.

fact: Bibliomania is a real condition
explanation: Bibliomania is the obsessive compulsion to collect books, even if you have no intention of reading them. It is distinct from 'tsundoku' (the Japanese term for piling up unread books), as bibliomania can interfere with daily life.

fact: Electric eels aren't eels
explanation: Despite the name and snake-like appearance, the electric eel is actually a knifefish. It is more closely related to catfish and carp than to true eels. They breathe air and must surface every 10 minutes or they will drown.

fact: There is a cloud of alcohol in space
explanation: In a gas cloud called Sagittarius B2, near the center of the Milky Way, astronomers have discovered huge quantities of vinyl alcohol and ethyl formate. Ethyl formate is the chemical that gives raspberries their flavor and smells like rum.

fact: The chainsaw was invented for childbirth (Confirmed)
explanation: This is a duplicate fact check: Reaffirming that the prototype chainsaw (osteotome) was a hand-cranked surgical tool for cutting through the pelvic bone to widen the birth canal.

fact: Your eyes jerk 3 times per second
explanation: Your eyes are never truly still. They make tiny, rapid movements called 'saccades' about 3 times every second. These movements allow the eye to constantly scan the environment and construct a clear, focused picture for the brain.

fact: Mount Everest grows 4mm a year
explanation: The collision of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates that created the Himalayas is still ongoing. As a result, Mount Everest is pushed upwards by approximately 4 millimeters (0.16 inches) every year.

fact: Pistachios are flammable
explanation: Pistachios have a high fat content and low water content. When stored in bulk (like within a shipping container), they can self-heat and spontaneously combust if not properly ventilated. They are classified as dangerous cargo.

fact: Pope Gregory IX declared war on cats
explanation: In the 13th century, Pope Gregory IX issued a papal bull (Vox in Rama) that associated black cats with devil worship. This led to mass exterminations of cats across Europe, which ironically may have helped the spread of the plague by increasing the rat population.

fact: The 'save' icon is a floppy disk
explanation: We still use the image of a 3.5-inch floppy disk as the universal symbol for 'saving' a file, even though floppy disks haven't been commonly used for decades. It is a classic example of a skeuomorph that has outlived its physical counterpart.

fact: Starfish don't have blood
explanation: Starfish (sea stars) do not have a circulatory system like mammals. Instead, they use a water vascular system. They pump filtered seawater through their bodies to transport nutrients and oxygen to their vital organs.

fact: Buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo...
explanation: The sentence 'Buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo' is a grammatically correct sentence in English. It uses three meanings of the word: the city (Buffalo, NY), the animal (buffalo), and the verb (to bully).

fact: Your footprints are unique
explanation: Just like fingerprints, the ridges and lines on your toes and the soles of your feet are unique to you. In some hospitals, newborn babies are footprinted instead of fingerprinted for identification purposes.

fact: The sun is white, not yellow
explanation: If you looked at the Sun from space, it would appear pure white. It only looks yellow (or red/orange) from Earth because our atmosphere scatters the shorter wavelengths of light (blues and violets), leaving the longer yellow/red wavelengths to reach our eyes.

fact: Cars were seen as environmental saviors
explanation: In the late 19th century, major cities were drowning in horse manure. The automobile was hailed as a 'green' solution to pollution because it didn't leave piles of waste in the streets. They didn't foresee smog and carbon emissions.

fact: Bananas are radioactive
explanation: Bananas are rich in potassium, and a small fraction of natural potassium is the radioactive isotope Potassium-40. However, you'd have to eat 10 million bananas at once to die of radiation poisoning. We even use the 'Banana Equivalent Dose' as a unit of measurement.

fact: Sloths have moths living in their fur
explanation: Sloths are moving ecosystems. Their fur contains a symbiotic relationship involving algae (which makes them green) and 'sloth moths'. The moths live in the fur, lay eggs in the sloth's poop, and feed on the algae, which helps camouflage the sloth.

fact: Venus flytraps can count
explanation: To save energy, a Venus flytrap doesn't close for just anything. It waits for two tickles of its trigger hairs within 20 seconds to snap shut. It waits for three more tickles before releasing digestive enzymes to ensure it has caught a live bug.

fact: The Moon is rusting
explanation: Rust (hematite) requires water and oxygen, which the Moon lacks. However, trace amounts of oxygen from Earth's upper atmosphere are traveling to the Moon via the Earth's magnetic tail, reacting with polar water ice to create rust spots.

fact: Treadmills were prison torture devices
explanation: In 1818, English engineer Sir William Cubitt invented the 'tread-wheel' to punish idle prisoners. Convicts were forced to climb the rotating steps for hours to grind grain or pump water. It was physically devastating and abolished in 1898.

fact: Cotton candy was invented by a dentist
explanation: In 1897, dentist William Morrison teamed up with confectioner John C. Wharton to invent the 'electric candy machine'. They debuted 'Fairy Floss' (now cotton candy) at the 1904 World's Fair, selling boxes of pure sugar to thousands.

fact: Pineapples eat you back
explanation: When you eat fresh pineapple, you might feel a tingling sensation. This is because it contains bromelain, an enzyme that breaks down proteins. Essentially, while you are eating the pineapple, the pineapple is slowly digesting the inside of your mouth.

fact: Mona Lisa has no eyebrows
explanation: Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece is famous for her gaze, but she lacks eyebrows and eyelashes. High-resolution scans suggest she originally had them, but they may have eroded over time due to over-cleaning by restorers in previous centuries.

fact: Ketchup has a speed limit
explanation: Heinz Ketchup is famous for being thick. In fact, if the ketchup flows out of the bottle faster than 0.028 miles per hour (roughly 1.3 cm per second) in the factory, it is considered too watery and is rejected for sale.

fact: Chip bags are filled with nitrogen
explanation: The 'air' in potato chip bags isn't oxygen, which would make the chips go stale and rancid. It is nearly 100% nitrogen gas. The nitrogen keeps the chips crisp and creates a cushion to prevent crushing during shipping.

fact: Humans have invisible stripes
explanation: We have 'Blaschko's lines' patterned across our skin, tracing the migration of embryonic cells. They are normally invisible, but under UV light or certain skin conditions (like chimerism), V-shapes on the back and swirls on the chest appear.

fact: Champagne corks launch at 25 mph
explanation: There is a lot of pressure in a champagne bottle (90 psi, similar to a bus tire). When popped, a cork can fly at speeds of up to 25 mph (40 km/h). This is why eye injuries from flying corks are surprisingly common.

fact: Octopuses have brains in their arms
explanation: An octopus has a central brain, but two-thirds of its neurons are distributed in its eight arms. This allows the arms to act independentlyâ€”tasting, touching, and movingâ€”without constantly checking in with the main brain.

fact: A con artist sold the Eiffel Tower twice
explanation: In 1925, Victor Lustig read that the Eiffel Tower was becoming expensive to maintain. He posed as a government official and convinced a scrap metal dealer to buy it for parts. He took the money and fled. He later tried the same scam again but failed.

fact: Lighters were invented before matches
explanation: The first lighter, Dobereiner's Lamp, was invented in 1823. The friction match wasn't invented until 1826 by John Walker. The early lighter was dangerous and bulky, using hydrogen gas and platinum, but technically predated the matchstick.

fact: Harvard is older than Calculus
explanation: Harvard University was founded in 1636. Calculus was not developed by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Leibniz until the late 17th century (around 1666-1684). This means for the first few decades, Harvard students couldn't study calculus.

fact: A Samurai could have sent a fax
explanation: The samurai caste was abolished in Japan in 1868. The first commercial fax machine (the pantelegraph) was patented and operating in the 1860s (running between Paris and Lyon in 1865). So, a samurai could theoretically have sent a fax.

fact: Betty White is older than sliced bread
explanation: The legendary actress Betty White was born in January 1922. The machine that automatically sliced and wrapped bread wasn't invented and used commercially until July 1928. She was literally the greatest thing *before* sliced bread.

fact: Pink was originally a boy's color
explanation: In the early 20th century, pink was considered a stronger, bolder color suitable for boys (a derivative of red), while blue was seen as delicate and dainty, suitable for girls. The gender norms switched to what we know today around the 1940s.

fact: Fanta was created in Nazi Germany
explanation: During WWII, a trade embargo prevented Coca-Cola Germany from importing the syrup needed to make Coke. To keep the factory running, they created a new drink using available leftovers like apple fiber and whey. They called it Fanta (from 'Fantasie').

fact: Corn Flakes were anti-masturbation food
explanation: Dr. John Harvey Kellogg was a devout Seventh-day Adventist who believed that bland foods reduced sexual urges. He invented Corn Flakes as a 'healthy, ready-to-eat anti-aphrodisiac' to prevent masturbation among his patients.

fact: Viagra was for heart conditions
explanation: Pfizer originally developed Sildenafil (Viagra) to treat high blood pressure and angina (chest pain). During clinical trials, male patients reported a peculiar side effect. The company pivoted marketing from heart health to erectile dysfunction.

fact: Bubble wrap was originally wallpaper
explanation: In 1957, two engineers sealed two shower curtains together to create a textured, bubble-filled wallpaper. It was a flop as decor. They later tried to sell it as greenhouse insulation, before realizing its potential as packaging material for IBM computers.

fact: Post-it Notes were a glue failure
explanation: Dr. Spencer Silver at 3M was trying to stick aircraft parts together with a super-strong adhesive. Instead, he accidentally created a weak, pressure-sensitive adhesive that peeled off easily. Years later, it was used to stick bookmarks, creating the Post-it.

fact: Slinky was for stabilizing ships
explanation: Mechanical engineer Richard James was trying to design a spring to keep sensitive ship equipment steady at sea. When he knocked one off a shelf and watched it 'walk' down a stack of books, he realized it would make a great toy.

fact: Play-Doh was wallpaper cleaner
explanation: Before it was a toy, Play-Doh was a pliable, non-toxic compound sold to remove soot from coal furnaces off of wallpaper. As oil heating replaced coal, sales dropped, until they realized nursery schools were using it for arts and crafts.

fact: Potato chips were revenge
explanation: In 1853, chef George Crum was annoyed by a customer (Cornelius Vanderbilt) who kept sending his fried potatoes back for being too thick and soggy. Crum sliced the potatoes paper-thin, fried them to a crisp, and oversalted them as a prank. The customer loved them.

fact: Tea bags were a misunderstanding
explanation: In 1908, tea merchant Thomas Sullivan sent samples of his tea in small silk bags to save money on packaging. Customers assumed the bags were meant to be dunked in hot water directly, creating the modern tea bag by accident.

fact: Popsicles were invented by an 11-year-old
explanation: In 1905, 11-year-old Frank Epperson left a cup of soda powder and water with a stirring stick in it on his porch overnight. It froze. He pulled the stick out and ate the ice. He patented the 'Epsicle' years later, which his kids called 'Pop's 'sicle'.

fact: Penicillin was a moldy mistake
explanation: Alexander Fleming returned from vacation in 1928 to find a petri dish of Staphylococcus bacteria that he had left uncovered. Mold (Penicillium) had grown on it, killing the surrounding bacteria. This accident led to the world's first antibiotic.

fact: Super Glue was a gun sight failure
explanation: Dr. Harry Coover was trying to make clear plastic gun sights for WWII soldiers in 1942. The formula he created (cyanoacrylate) was a failure because it stuck to everything it touched. It wasn't sold as a glue (Super Glue) until 1958.

fact: Pac-Man was inspired by pizza
explanation: Video game designer Toru Iwatani was eating a pizza. He took one slice, looked at the remaining shape, and saw a head with an open mouth. This simple visual inspired the character design for Pac-Man (originally Puck-Man).

fact: Mario was originally a carpenter
explanation: When Mario first appeared in 'Donkey Kong' (1981), he was a carpenter named 'Jumpman' and the setting was a construction site. He didn't become a plumber named Mario until 'Mario Bros.' was released in 1983, featuring pipes.

fact: The Tetris Effect is real
explanation: If you play Tetris for a long time, you might start seeing falling blocks when you close your eyes or try to mentally fit real-world objects together. This hallucination, caused by devoting so much time to an activity, is officially called the 'Tetris Effect'.

fact: First text message was 'Merry Christmas'
explanation: The world's first SMS was sent on December 3, 1992, by engineer Neil Papworth. He sent it from a computer to the Orbitel 901 handset of Vodafone director Richard Jarvis. The message simply read: 'Merry Christmas'.

fact: Google was originally called BackRub
explanation: Larry Page and Sergey Brin originally named their search engine 'BackRub' in 1996 because it analyzed the 'backlinks' to understand how important a website was. While descriptive, it didn't quite have the branding power of Google (a play on googol).

fact: Amazon was almost named Cadabra
explanation: Jeff Bezos initially incorporated his company as 'Cadabra' (as in abracadabra). However, his lawyer misheard the name over the phone as 'Cadaver' (a dead body). Bezos quickly changed it to Amazon, to suggest scale and appear first in alphabetical lists.

fact: Bluetooth is named after a Viking
explanation: The technology is named after King Harald 'Bluetooth' Gormsson, a 10th-century Viking king who united Denmark and Norway. The logo is a combination (bindrune) of his initials in Nordic runes: H (áš¼) and B (á›’).

fact: WiFi was co-invented by an actress
explanation: Hollywood star Hedy Lamarr was also an inventor. During WWII, she co-developed a frequency-hopping spread spectrum technology to guide torpedoes without jamming. This concept later became the foundational technology for WiFi and Bluetooth.

fact: CAPTCHA helps digitize books
explanation: When you type in those squiggly words to prove you aren't a robot (reCAPTCHA), you are often helping to digitize old books. One word is a test, the other is scanned text that a computer couldn't read, and your input helps transcribe it.

fact: Most common password is '123456'
explanation: Despite decades of warnings, '123456' remains the most commonly used password worldwide, followed closely by 'password' and '123456789'. This makes millions of accounts incredibly easy for hackers to breach.

fact: Email Spam is named after Monty Python
explanation: The term 'Spam' (for unwanted junk email) comes from a Monty Python sketch where a cafÃ© menu consists almost entirely of Spam, and vikings chant 'Spam, Spam, Spam' drowning out all other conversationâ€”just like junk mail drowns out real email.

fact: Domain names were free until 1995
explanation: Before 1995, you could register a domain name for free. Network Solutions was granted the monopoly to charge for domains (initially $100 per year) starting in September 1995, changing the internet from an academic network to a commercial one.

fact: First .com was Symbolics.com
explanation: The very first commercial domain name ever registered was Symbolics.com on March 15, 1985. It belonged to a computer manufacturer. The site still exists today as a digital museum of internet history.

fact: The 'Cloud' is underwater
explanation: We think of the internet as being in the air (cloud), but 99% of international data is transmitted via massive fiber-optic cables lying on the bottom of the ocean. These cables are occasionally bitten by sharks.
Data storage prices have plummeted. In 1980, the price of one gigabyte of hard drive space was roughly $100,000 (and the drive weighed 500 lbs). Today, a gigabyte of storage costs less than a penny.

fact: GPS is free thanks to the US Air Force
explanation: The Global Positioning System (GPS) is owned and operated by the US government (specifically the Space Force/Air Force). It costs about $2 million a day to maintain, but it is provided free to the entire world as a public good.

fact: Sony started making rice cookers
explanation: Before replacing the Walkman or PlayStation, Sony was a small radio repair shop. Their very first product was an electric rice cooker. It was a failure because it didn't cook the rice evenly, producing either mush or burnt rice.

fact: Samsung started as a noodle shop
explanation: Samsung is now a tech giant, but it was founded in 1938 by Lee Byung-chul as a small trading company selling noodles, locally grown groceries, and dried fish to China. They didn't enter electronics until the late 1960s.

fact: Lamborghini started with tractors
explanation: Ferruccio Lamborghini was a successful tractor manufacturer. He only decided to make sports cars because he was insulted by Enzo Ferrari, who told him 'You may be able to drive a tractor, but you will never be able to handle a Ferrari properly'.

fact: Abercrombie sold shotguns
explanation: Abercrombie & Fitch wasn't always a teen fashion mall brand. It started as an elite sporting goods store for safari gear, tents, and shotguns. Ernest Hemingway and Theodore Roosevelt were famous customers who bought their guns there.

fact: The Pyramids were originally white
explanation: The Great Pyramids of Giza didn't look like rough stone blocks when they were built. They were originally encased in smooth, highly polished white limestone that would have reflected the sun like a beacon. The gold capstone at the top would have dazzled for miles.

fact: Statue of Liberty was copper
explanation: When France gifted the Statue of Liberty to the USA in 1886, it was shiny reddish-brown copper (like a penny). Over about 30 years, oxidation turned it into the iconic blue-green 'verdigris' patina we see today.

fact: The Sphinx had a beard
explanation: The Great Sphinx of Giza originally had a braided beard, which was a symbol of pharaonic power. Today, fragments of that beard are not in Egypt, but in the British Museum in London.

fact: The Colosseum had a roof
explanation: Spectators in ancient Rome didn't sit in the baking sun. The Colosseum featured a massive retractable awning system called the 'velarium'. It was operated by sailors from the Roman navy to shade the crowd.

fact: Vikings used urine to make fire
explanation: Vikings would boil touchwood fungus in human urine. The sodium nitrate in the urine would allow the fungus to smolder for days without burning out, allowing them to carry fire from one campsite to another easily.

fact: Pirates wore eye patches for night vision
explanation: It wasn't just for missing eyes. Pirates had to constantly move between the bright sunlight on deck and the dark hold of the ship. Keeping one eye covered allowed them to instantly adapt to darkness by switching the patch to the other eye.

fact: Ninjas wore blue, not black
explanation: Real historical ninjas did not wear all-black jumpsuits, which would silhouette them against the night sky. They wore dark blue farmers' clothing to blend in with the dark, or disguised themselves as traveling monks or merchants.

fact: Cowboys preferred bowler hats
explanation: The '10-gallon' cowboy hat is a Hollywood invention. Real Wild West figures like Billy the Kid and Butch Cassidy wore bowler hats (derbies) because they were less likely to blow off in the wind while riding a horse.

fact: Pilgrims didn't wear buckles on hats
explanation: The popular image of Pilgrims wearing hats and shoes with big gold buckles is false. Buckles were expensive fashion accessories that didn't become popular until decades later. Pilgrims used laces and leather ties.

fact: George Washington didn't have wooden teeth
explanation: The first US President's dentures were not made of wood. They were a horrifying mix of hippopotamus ivory, gold springs, lead, and human teeth (some purchased from slaves). They were very painful to wear.

fact: Franklin wanted a turkey national bird
explanation: Benjamin Franklin was not fond of the Bald Eagle, calling it a 'bird of bad moral character' because it steals food. He wrote that the Turkey was a 'much more respectable bird' and a true native of America.

fact: The White House was originally gray
explanation: When it was built, the President's house was gray sandstone. It was painted white in 1814 to hide the burn marks after British soldiers set it on fire during the War of 1812. The name 'White House' wasn't official until Theodore Roosevelt.

fact: Longest war was 335 years, 0 deaths
explanation: The Three Hundred and Thirty Five Years' War between the Netherlands and the Isles of Scilly lasted from 1651 to 1986. Remarkably, not a single shot was fired and no one was killed. They simply forgot to sign a peace treaty for three centuries.

fact: The 100 Years War lasted 116 years
explanation: Historians rounded down. The conflict between England and France actually ran from 1337 to 1453 (116 years). It wasn't one continuous battle, but a series of intermittent conflicts spread over that period.

fact: Germany paid off WWI in 2010
explanation: The Treaty of Versailles (1919) imposed massive reparations on Germany for World War I. Germany finally made the very last payment of 70 million euros on October 3, 2010, nearly 92 years after the war ended.

fact: Titanic's two sister ships also crashed
explanation: The Titanic was one of three Olympic-class ships. The Britannic sank after hitting a mine in WWI. The Olympic crashed into a British warship (HMS Hawke) but survived and was nicknamed 'Old Reliable'.

fact: Unsinkable Sam the cat
explanation: A cat named 'Unsinkable Sam' (originally Oscar) survived the sinking of three different ships during WWII: the German Bismarck, the British HMS Cossack, and the HMS Ark Royal. He retired to a sailor's home in Belfast.

fact: A bear served in the Polish Army
explanation: Wojtek was a Syrian brown bear bought by Polish soldiers in WWII. He was officially enlisted as a private, given a paybook and rations (which he swapped for beer). He helped carry heavy artillery shells during the Battle of Monte Cassino.

fact: A dog was mayor for 4 terms
explanation: Duke, a Great Pyrenees, was elected mayor of Cormorant, Minnesota, in 2014. He was so popular he was re-elected three times, serving until his retirement in 2018. His salary was paid in dog food.

fact: A penguin is a knight
explanation: Sir Nils Olav III is a king penguin residing in Edinburgh Zoo. He is the mascot and Colonel-in-Chief of the Norwegian King's Guard. He was knighted in 2008 and promoted to Brigadier in 2016.

fact: Stubby the dog was a Sergeant
explanation: Sergeant Stubby was a stray dog who served with the US Army in WWI. He participated in 17 battles, saved his regiment from mustard gas attacks (he could smell it early), and even caught a German spy by biting him on the pants.

fact: Cherophobia is fear of happiness
explanation: Cherophobia is not the fear of the singer Cher. It comes from the Greek 'chairo' (to rejoice). People with this phobia are afraid to be happy because they believe that something bad or tragic will inevitably happen soon after.

fact: Hippopotomonstrosesquippedaliophobia
explanation: Whoever named phobias had a cruel sense of humor. 'Hippopotomonstrosesquippedaliophobia' is the official name for the fear of long words. It is one of the longest words in the dictionary.

fact: Pogonophobia is fear of beards
explanation: If you are terrified of Santa Claus or hipsters, you might have pogonophobiaâ€”the irrational, persistent, and often unwarranted fear of beards. It has been a recorded condition since the 1850s.

fact: Anatidaephobia is the duck fear
explanation: Anatidaephobia is a semi-fictional phobia defined by Gary Larson (The Far Side) as 'the fear that somewhere, somehow, a duck is watching you'. While not clinically recognized, the concept highlights the absurdity of specific anxieties.

fact: Omphalophobia is fear of belly buttons
explanation: People with omphalophobia have a terror of belly buttons. They cannot touch their own navel, nor can they look at or touch others'. They often believe their insides might spill out if the button is unraveled.

fact: Trypophobia is fear of holes
explanation: Trypophobia is the aversion to clusters of small holes or bumps, such as those seen on a lotus seed pod, a honeycomb, or a sponge. Researchers believe it may be an evolutionary survival response to avoid diseased tissue or parasites.

fact: A group of pugs is a 'grumble'
explanation: Collective nouns for dog breeds are rare, but pugs have their own. A group of three or more pugs is affectionately known as a 'grumble', likely descriptive of the snorting and snuffling sounds they make due to their flat faces.

fact: A group of ferrets is a 'business'
explanation: The collective noun for a group of ferrets is a 'business'. The term supposedly comes from a modernized form of the word 'busyness', describing their hyperactive, curious, and constantly moving nature.

fact: A group of jellyfish is a 'smack'
explanation: While they glide gracefully, a group of jellyfish is called a 'smack', 'bloom', or 'swarm'. 'Smack' is the most distinctive term, possibly referring to the sensation if you swim into one.

fact: A group of rhinos is a 'crash'
explanation: Given that rhinoceroses can run at 30 mph and have poor eyesight, 'crash' seems like an appropriate name for a group of them. When they charge, they can indeed crash through almost anything in their path.

fact: A group of porcupines is a 'prickle'
explanation: Another fitting name: a family or group of porcupines is called a 'prickle'. It perfectly describes their defining featureâ€”the sharp quills that cover their bodies for defense.

fact: Baby porcupines are 'porcupettes'
explanation: The official name for a baby porcupine is a 'porcupette'. They are born with soft, bendable quills that harden rapidly within a few days of birth to provide protection.

fact: Baby puffins are 'pufflings'
explanation: A baby puffin is adorably called a 'puffling'. They are gray and fluffy balls of down feathers and look quite different from their black-and-white, colorful-beaked parents.

fact: Platypuses sweat milk
explanation: The platypus is a monotreme (egg-laying mammal). Although they produce milk for their young, they have no nipples. Instead, they sweat milk out through patches of skin on their stomach, and the babies lap it up from the fur.

fact: Platypuses are venomous
explanation: The male platypus has a hollow spur on its hind legs that is connected to a venom gland. The venom is not lethal to humans, but it causes excruciating pain that cannot be relieved by morphine and can last for months.

fact: Platypuses glow under UV light
explanation: In 2020, scientists discovered that platypus fur is biofluorescent. Under ultraviolet (black) light, their normally brown fur glows a strange blue-green color. They are one of the few mammals known to do this.

fact: Kangaroos can't walk backwards
explanation: Due to their massive, muscular tails and the shape of their legs, kangaroos cannot walk or hop backwards. This anatomical limitation makes them symbol of 'always moving forward'.

fact: Emus are bulletproof (Sort of)
explanation: During the 'Great Emu War' of 1932, Australian soldiers found emus surprisingly hard to kill. Their dense feathers and thick skin acted as natural armor, absorbing machine gun bullets unless hit in a vital organ.

fact: Australia lost a war to Emus
explanation: In 1932, the Australian military declared war on 20,000 emus destroying crops. Armed with Lewis machine guns, the soldiers failed to curb the population as the birds outmaneuvered them. The military withdrew, and the emus technically won.

fact: Koalas sleep 22 hours a day
explanation: Koalas aren't lazy; their diet is just terrible. Eucalyptus leaves are low in energy and toxic. Digesting them takes so much metabolic energy that koalas have to sleep or rest for up to 22 hours a day to conserve strength.

fact: Sloths poop once a week
explanation: Sloths have an incredibly slow metabolism. They only descend from their trees once a week to defecate on the ground. This weekly 'poop dance' is risky, as it is the only time they are vulnerable to predators like jaguars.

fact: Armadillo shells are bulletproof
explanation: In 2017, a Texas man shot at an armadillo in his yard with a .38 revolver. The bullet ricocheted off the animal's hard shell, flew back, and hit the man in the jaw. The armadillo walked away unharmed.

fact: Ants take 250 naps a day
explanation: Ants don't sleep in one long block like humans. Instead, worker ants take approximately 250 tiny 'power naps' per day, each lasting just over a minute. This totals about 4 to 5 hours of sleep daily.

fact: Ants don't have lungs
explanation: Because they are so small, ants don't need lungs to force air in and out. They breathe through tiny holes in their sides called spiracles. Oxygen enters and carbon dioxide exits passively through these tubes.

fact: Queen ants can live 30 years
explanation: While worker ants live only for a few months, the queen Lasius niger ant has been recorded living for up to 30 years in captivity. This makes them one of the longest-living insects on the planet.

fact: Only honey bees die after stinging
explanation: It's a myth that all bees die after stinging. Only the honey bee has a barbed stinger that gets stuck in mammalian skin, ripping her abdomen apart when she flies away. Bumblebees and wasps have smooth stingers and can sting repeatedly.

fact: Mosquitoes are the deadliest animal
explanation: When counting human deaths, the mosquito is the most dangerous creature on Earth. By spreading malaria, dengue, and yellow fever, they are responsible for over 725,000 human deaths every year. Sharks kill fewer than 10.

fact: Cows kill more people than sharks
explanation: In the US alone, cows kill about 22 people per year (usually by kicking or crushing farmers). Sharks, by comparison, kill only about 1 person per year in the US and fewer than 10 globally. You are safer in the ocean than in a field.

fact: Vending machines kill more than sharks
explanation: Statistically, you are 4 times more likely to be crushed to death by a vending machine (usually while shaking it for a stuck snack) than you are to be bitten by a shark. Vending machines cause roughly 13 deaths per year.

fact: Coconuts kill more people than sharks
explanation: While the exact number is debated, falling coconuts are often cited as causing roughly 150 deaths per year worldwide. Whether the number is precise or not, you are still statistically more likely to be bonked by a fruit than eaten by a Great White.

fact: Nintendo made 'Love Hotels'
explanation: In the 1960s, before finding success with video games, Nintendo tried several different business ventures to survive. These included a taxi company, a TV network, selling instant rice, and even running a chain of 'Love Hotels' (short-stay hotels for couples) in Japan.

fact: Barbie's full name is Barbara Millicent Roberts
explanation: The iconic doll isn't just 'Barbie'. Her fictional backstory gives her the full name Barbara Millicent Roberts. She is from the fictional town of Willows, Wisconsin. Her boyfriend Ken's full name is Kenneth Carson.

fact: Cookie Monster's real name is Sid
explanation: In a 2004 episode of Sesame Street, the Cookie Monster revealed that before he started eating cookies, his name was Sid. It seems 'Cookie Monster' is just a nickname describing his primary lifestyle choice.

fact: Wombats poop cubes
explanation: This unique shape is formed in the final section of the wombat's intestine. The cubic shape stops the poop from rolling away, which is vital because wombats use piles of scat to mark their territory on rocks and logs.

fact: Ancient Olympics were performed naked
explanation: In ancient Greece, athletes competed in the nude. The word 'gymnasium' actually comes from the Greek word 'gymnos', which means 'naked'. They would oil their bodies before competing in events like wrestling and running.

fact: One day on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days
explanation: Mercury has a very slow rotation but a fast orbit. It takes 59 Earth days to rotate once on its axis, but because of its movement around the Sun, a full day-night cycle (sunrise to sunrise) takes 176 Earth days.

fact: Some frogs can freeze solid and survive
explanation: The Wood Frog found in North America can freeze almost completely solid during winter. Its heart stops beating and its breathing ceases. It survives by producing high levels of glucose (sugar) that act as an antifreeze to protect its cells.

fact: 'E' is the most common letter
explanation: In the English language, the letter 'E' appears in approximately 11% of all words, making it the most frequently used letter. The least common is 'Z'.

fact: McDonald's once made bubblegum broccoli
explanation: In an attempt to get kids to eat healthier, McDonald's developed broccoli that tasted like bubblegum. Unsurprisingly, the focus groups of children were confused and disgusted by the flavor clash, and it never launched.

fact: Spartan warriors used iron bars as money
explanation: Legend says that Lycurgus, the lawgiver of Sparta, banned gold and silver coins. Instead, Spartans used heavy, cumbersome iron bars (pelanors) as currency. This was to discourage greed, theft, and foreign trade.

fact: Hummingbirds are the only birds that fly backwards
explanation: Their wings are attached to their shoulders in a unique way that allows them to rotate nearly 180 degrees. This enables them to hover in place and fly backwards with precision, acting more like insects than other birds.

fact: Picasso could draw before he could walk
explanation: Pablo Picasso was a child prodigy. His first word was reportedly 'piz, piz', a shortening of 'lapiz', the Spanish word for pencil. He began formal art training at age 7.

fact: There are no mosquitoes in Iceland
explanation: Iceland is one of the very few habitable places on Earth that is completely free of mosquitoes. The climate is too unstable for their life cycle; sudden temperature drops in winter kill the larvae before they can mature.

fact: Your small intestine is 20 feet long
explanation: It's called 'small' because of its diameter (about 1 inch), not its length. The small intestine is coiled up inside your abdomen and measures about 20 feet (6 meters) long, whereas the large intestine is only about 5 feet long.

fact: The first VCR was the size of a piano
explanation: The Ampex VRX-1000, released in 1956, was the first commercial videotape recorder. It cost $50,000 (about $500,000 today) and was so large it required an entire console the size of a grand piano to operate.

fact: A snail has 14,000 teeth
explanation: Snails have a tongue-like structure called a radula, which is covered in rows of tiny, microscopic teeth made of chitin. A garden snail can have over 14,000 of these teeth, which they use to scrape food off surfaces.

fact: Oxford has a bell that has rung for 1,200 years
explanation: Old Tom, the bell at Christ Church, Oxford, rings 101 times every night at 9:05 PM. It has been doing this (with breaks for repair) for centuries, originally to signal the college gates closing for the 101 original scholars.

fact: Water can boil and freeze at the same time
explanation: This is called the 'triple point'. At a specific pressure (0.006 atm) and temperature (0.01Â°C), water can exist as a gas, liquid, and solid simultaneously. It looks like boiling water with ice floating in it.

fact: Chocolate was once used as currency
explanation: The ancient Aztecs and Mayans valued cacao beans so highly that they used them as money. A rabbit might cost 10 beans, while a slave could cost 100. Counterfeiters would even fill empty bean shells with mud.

fact: Reindeer eyes change color
explanation: Reindeer (Caribou) eyes change color with the seasons. In the summer, they are gold to handle the constant sunlight. In the winter, they turn deep blue to scatter light and improve night vision during the endless Arctic darkness.

fact: You are taller in the morning
explanation: Throughout the day, gravity compresses the cartilage discs in your spine. When you wake up, you are about 1 cm taller than you are when you go to bed, as the discs rehydrate and expand while you are lying down.

fact: Ben Franklin invented flippers
explanation: Benjamin Franklin was an avid swimmer. At age 11, he invented a pair of oval wooden planks with holes for his thumbs, which he used as hand paddles to swim faster. He later realized they fatigued his wrists.

fact: Nomophobia is fear of no phone
explanation: Nomophobia (NO MObile PHone PhoBIA) is the anxiety caused by being without your mobile phone or being unable to use it. Symptoms include panic, sweating, and disorientation when the battery dies or signal is lost.

fact: Saturn has hexagonal storms
explanation: At Saturn's north pole, there is a massive storm cloud pattern that is shaped like a perfect hexagon. Each side of the hexagon is wider than Earth. Scientists believe it is caused by standing waves in the planet's atmospheric jet stream.

fact: QWERTY was designed to slow you down
explanation: The QWERTY keyboard layout was created by Christopher Sholes in 1873 for typewriters. He placed common letter pairs apart to prevent the mechanical typebars from jamming. It wasn't designed for speed, but for mechanical reliability.

fact: Hitler was nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize
explanation: In 1939, a Swedish politician named E.G.C. Brandt nominated Adolf Hitler for the Nobel Peace Prize. It was intended as a satirical joke and a criticism of the political climate, but the nomination was real and had to be formally withdrawn.

fact: Lobsters pee out of their faces
explanation: Lobsters have urine-release nozzles located right under their eyes. They use this not just for waste, but to communicate. They urinate on each other during fights and courtship to send chemical signals.

fact: Peanuts are not nuts
explanation: Botanically speaking, peanuts are legumes, related to beans, lentils, and peas. Unlike true nuts (like walnuts or almonds) that grow on trees, peanuts grow underground, which is why they are also called groundnuts.

fact: There is a planet made of diamond
explanation: The exoplanet 55 Cancri e is twice the size of Earth and is believed to have a surface largely composed of graphite and diamond. It is likely the result of a carbon-rich star system and immense pressure.

fact: Cleopatra lived closer to the iPad than the Pyramids
explanation: Cleopatra VII died in 30 BC. The Great Pyramid of Giza was built around 2560 BC. This means she lived over 2,500 years after the pyramids were built, but only about 2,000 years before the first iPad was released (2010).

fact: Babies don't have kneecaps
explanation: When babies are born, their kneecaps (patella) are made of soft cartilage, not bone. This allows for flexibility during birth and growth. They don't fully ossify into hard bone until the child is about 3 to 5 years old.

fact: Sharks existed before trees
explanation: Sharks first appeared in the fossil record about 400 million years ago. The earliest trees (Archaeopteris) didn't evolve until about 350 million years ago. Sharks are essentially living fossils.

fact: Russia has a larger surface area than Pluto
explanation: Russia is the largest country on Earth, with a surface area of about 17 million square kilometers. Pluto, the dwarf planet, has a surface area of roughly 16.7 million square kilometers. Russia is literally bigger than a planet.

fact: Strawberries are not berries
explanation: Botanically, a berry must develop from a single ovary and have seeds on the inside. Strawberries have seeds on the outside (achenes). However, bananas, pumpkins, and watermelons are technically classified as berries.

fact: The dot over an 'i' is called a tittle
explanation: That little dot above the lowercase 'i' and 'j' has a name. It is called a 'tittle'. The phrase 'to a T' is thought to be derived from 'to a tittle', meaning down to the smallest detail.

fact: Ketchup was sold as medicine
explanation: In 1834, Dr. John Cook Bennett sold ketchup as a cure for indigestion, jaundice, and diarrhea. He even turned it into pill form. It wasn't until later that it became purely a condiment.

fact: Butterflies taste with their feet
explanation: Butterflies have taste sensors on their legs. When they land on a flower or leaf, they can instantly taste whether it is a suitable place to lay eggs (food for caterpillars) or if there is nectar available.

fact: A full NASA suit costs $12 million
explanation: The white EVA suits (Extravehicular Mobility Units) used by NASA astronauts were built in 1974. At the time, they cost between $15 million to $22 million. Today, with inflation, that cost would be roughly $150 million per suit.

fact: Heroin was a cough syrup for kids
explanation: In the 1890s, the Bayer pharmaceutical company marketed Heroin as a non-addictive substitute for morphine and as a cough suppressant for children. It was legal and available over the counter.

fact: Your phone has more computing power than NASA in 1969
explanation: The Apollo Guidance Computer used to land men on the moon had a processor running at 0.043 MHz and 64KB of memory. A modern smartphone is millions of times more powerful than the combined computing power of all of NASA in 1969.

fact: Turtles can breathe through their butts
explanation: Many turtle species (like the Painted Turtle) hibernate underwater. Since they cannot surface for air, they absorb oxygen from the water through their cloaca (the all-purpose opening for waste and reproduction) in a process called cloacal respiration.

fact: French Fries are originally Belgian
explanation: Despite the name, fries likely originated in Belgium. American soldiers stationed in Belgium during WWI tasted them and called them 'French fries' because the official language of the Belgian army was French at the time.

fact: Napoleon was not short
explanation: Napoleon Bonaparte was recorded as 5 feet 2 inches at his death. However, this was in French inches (which were longer than English inches). In modern measurements, he was about 5 feet 7 inches, which was actually slightly above average for a Frenchman in the 1800s.

fact: The longest English word has 189,819 letters
explanation: The chemical name for the protein Titin is the longest word in the world. It would take over 3 hours to pronounce. Dictionaries don't include it for practical reasons.

fact: The shortest war lasted 38 minutes
explanation: The Anglo-Zanzibar War of 1896 is the shortest recorded war in history. After the Sultan of Zanzibar refused to step down, British warships bombarded the palace. The Sultan surrendered 38 minutes later.

fact: Giraffes have black tongues
explanation: A giraffe's tongue can be up to 20 inches long. It is dark purple or black in color, likely to prevent it from getting sunburned as the giraffe spends most of its day eating leaves from the tops of trees.

fact: Apple has more cash than the US Government
explanation: At various points in the last decade (notably 2011 and 2014), Apple's cash reserves exceeded the operating cash balance of the US Treasury. Essentially, the tech company had more spending money on hand than the most powerful nation on Earth.

fact: Male seahorses give birth
explanation: Seahorses are the only species where the male carries the unborn young. The female deposits eggs into the male's brood pouch, where he fertilizes them and carries them until they hatch.

fact: Alaska is the most eastern and western state
explanation: Alaska is clearly the most northern and western state in the US. However, because the Aleutian Islands cross the 180th meridian (the International Date Line), they technically extend into the Eastern Hemisphere, making Alaska the most eastern state as well.

fact: The first computer bug was a real moth
explanation: In 1947, computer scientist Grace Hopper found a moth trapped in a relay of the Harvard Mark II computer, causing it to fail. She taped the moth into the logbook with the note 'First actual case of bug being found'. The term 'debugging' became standard.

fact: Cleopatra was Greek, not Egyptian
explanation: Cleopatra VII Philopator was a descendant of Ptolemy I Soter, a general of Alexander the Great. She was part of the Greek-speaking Ptolemaic dynasty that ruled Egypt. Unlike her ancestors, she was the first in her line to actually learn the Egyptian language.

fact: Chains used to be a cure for insanity
explanation: Before the 19th century reform of asylums, it was common belief that restraining mental patients in heavy iron chains would help 'ground' them and prevent manic episodes. Philippe Pinel famously ordered the chains removed in 1793.

fact: Elephants are the only mammal that can't jump
explanation: Due to their immense weight and the structure of their leg bones (which are stacked like pillars), elephants physically cannot lift all four feet off the ground at once. A jump would likely shatter their bones.

fact: Romans used urine to whiten teeth
explanation: Ancient Romans believed that urine (especially from Portugal, for some reason) was excellent for oral hygiene. The ammonia in urine acts as a bleaching agent. They would literally buy bottles of pee to use as mouthwash.

fact: You shed 40 pounds of skin in a lifetime
explanation: Your outer layer of skin (epidermis) completely replaces itself every 2-4 weeks. Over an average lifetime, a human sheds about 40 to 50 pounds of dead skin cells, much of which ends up as household dust.

fact: The first mouse was made of wood
explanation: In 1964, Douglas Engelbart invented the first computer mouse. It was a bulky wooden block with two metal wheels underneath to track movement. It was called a mouse because the cord resembled a tail.

fact: Crows recognize human faces
explanation: Researchers have proven that crows can remember individual human faces for years. If you are mean to a crow, it will remember you, dive-bomb you, and even teach its children and other crows to attack you specifically.

fact: Ketchup used to be fish sauce
explanation: The word 'ketchup' comes from the Hokkien Chinese word 'ke-tsiap', which was a fermented fish sauce (like soy sauce). British sailors brought it back and substituted mushrooms and walnuts. Tomatoes weren't added until 1812.

fact: Bananas are cloned
explanation: The Cavendish banana, which accounts for 99% of banana exports, is seedless and sterile. Every single banana you eat is a genetic clone propagated from cuttings. This makes the entire crop dangerously susceptible to a single disease (Panama Disease).

fact: Potatoes were illegal in France
explanation: Between 1748 and 1772, growing potatoes was banned in France because lawmakers believed they caused leprosy. It took pharmacist Antoine-Augustin Parmentier (who ate them as a prisoner of war) to convince the King they were safe.

fact: Sound cannot travel in space
explanation: Sound requires a medium (like air, water, or solid matter) to vibrate and travel. Since space is a near-perfect vacuum, there are no particles to carry the sound waves. No matter how big the explosion, space is silent.

fact: Your nose and ears never stop growing
explanation: While your bones stop growing after puberty, cartilage acts differently. Gravity causes the collagen and elastin in your nose and ear cartilage to break down and droop over time, making them appear to grow larger as you age.

fact: Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world
explanation: Canada is extremely soggy. It has an estimated 2 million lakes, with 563 of them being larger than 100 square kilometers. This accounts for about 60% of all the lakes on Earth combined.

fact: Cows have best friends
explanation: Research shows that cows form deep social bonds. They have a specific 'best friend' in the herd and become demonstrably stressed (higher heart rate, agitation) when separated from them.

fact: Dentures were wedding gifts
explanation: In the British Isles during the 19th century, it was common for people to have all their teeth extracted at a young age to avoid the pain of future tooth rot. A full set of dentures was considered a sensible and practical wedding gift.

fact: Octopuses have blue blood
explanation: Human blood is red because it uses iron (hemoglobin) to carry oxygen. Octopuses live in cold, low-oxygen water, so they evolved to use copper (hemocyanin) instead, which turns their blood blue.

fact: The pound sign (#) is an octothorpe
explanation: Before it was the 'hashtag', the '#' symbol was officially named the 'octothorpe' by Bell Labs engineers in the 1960s. 'Octo' refers to the eight points at the ends of the strokes, and 'thorpe' was likely just a suffix they liked.

fact: Neutron stars are dense
explanation: Neutron stars are the collapsed cores of massive stars. They are so incredibly dense that a single teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about 6 billion tonsâ€”roughly the same as Mount Everest.

fact: Spartans used bread to wipe hands
explanation: Napkins weren't a thing in ancient Greece. Spartans would use a piece of dough called 'apomagdalie' to wipe the grease from their fingers after eating. They would then usually feed the greasy dough to their dogs.

fact: Goats utilize accents
explanation: Researchers at Queen Mary University of London found that pygmy goats develop their own vocal accents as they grow older and socialize within their specific group, much like humans pick up regional dialects.

fact: The CIA used cats as spies
explanation: In the 1960s operation 'Acoustic Kitty', the CIA surgically implanted a microphone in a cat's ear and a transmitter in its skull. The plan was for the cat to eavesdrop on Soviet agents. On its first mission, the cat wandered into the street and was hit by a taxi.

fact: Your heart beats 100,000 times a day
explanation: The human heart is a tireless engine. Beating at an average resting rate, it pumps about 2,000 gallons of blood through your body every single day, tallying up to roughly 35 million beats per year.

fact: First webcam watched a coffee pot
explanation: In 1991, researchers at Cambridge University were tired of walking to the break room only to find the coffee pot empty. They set up a camera (the Trojan Room Coffee Pot) and wrote a program to display a live grayscale image of it on their desktops.

fact: A cloud can weigh 1 million pounds
explanation: Clouds look fluffy and light, but they are heavy water vapor. A typical cumulus cloud has a volume of about one cubic kilometer and a density of 0.5 grams per cubic meter, meaning the whole cloud weighs roughly 1.1 million pounds.

fact: Japan uses fax machines
explanation: Despite being a high-tech nation, Japan still heavily relies on fax machines for business and government documents. Stamps (hanko) are required for legality, and it's easier to stamp a physical paper and fax it than to use digital signatures.

fact: Calling 'shotgun' has a literal origin
explanation: In the Old West stagecoach era, the person entering the coach sat next to the driver. Their job was to carry a shotgun to ward off bandits and keep the horses calm. Hence, riding in the front passenger seat became 'riding shotgun'.

fact: High heels were for men
explanation: High heels were originally created for Persian soldiers in the 10th century. The heel helped lock their boots into the stirrups while riding horses, allowing them to shoot arrows more accurately. They didn't become a female fashion item until the 1600s.

fact: Wasabi is usually fake
explanation: Real wasabi is incredibly expensive to grow. Most 'wasabi' served in restaurants outside of high-end Japanese dining is actually just horseradish dyed green with food coloring and mustard.

fact: Hippos sweat blood (sort of)
explanation: Hippos secrete a reddish-orange oily fluid that acts as a natural sunscreen and moisturizer. It often looks like blood, leading to the myth, but it's actually an antiseptic secretion called 'blood sweat' or 'red sweat'.

fact: Flamingos are born gray
explanation: Flamingos are naturally gray or white. They only turn pink because of their diet, which consists of brine shrimp and blue-green algae that are rich in carotenoid pigments (canthaxanthin). Zoo flamingos will turn white if not fed special supplements.

fact: Polar bears have black skin
explanation: Underneath their thick white fur, polar bears have jet-black skin. This helps them absorb as much heat as possible from the sun. Their fur is actually transparent and hollow, reflecting light to appear white.

fact: Tigers have striped skin
explanation: Unlike most other patterned animals where the pattern is only on the fur, if you were to shave a tiger (which is not recommended), you would see that the stripes are tattooed onto their skin as well.

fact: Zebras are black with white stripes
explanation: Embryological evidence shows that zebras start out with dark skin and acquire their white stripes later in development. Therefore, they are technically black animals with white stripes, not the other way around.

fact: Sloths swim 3x faster than they walk
explanation: On land, sloths are painfully slow and clumsy. In water, however, they are surprisingly efficient swimmers. They use their long arms to do a doggy-paddle (or 'slothy-paddle') to cross rivers in search of mates or new territory.

fact: Heinz 57 is a made-up number
explanation: When Henry Heinz introduced the '57 Varieties' slogan in 1896, his company already sold over 60 products. He just picked '57' because he thought it was a lucky number (combining 5, his lucky number, and 7, his wife's).

fact: Honey bees communicate with dance
explanation: Honey bees perform a 'waggle dance' to tell other bees where to find food. The angle of the dance indicates direction relative to the sun, and the duration of the waggle indicates the distance to the flower patch.

fact: Humans glow in the dark
explanation: The human body actually emits a small amount of visible light (bioluminescence) due to metabolic reactions. However, the light is 1,000 times weaker than the human eye can perceive, so we need ultra-sensitive cameras to see it.

fact: Venus spins backwards
explanation: Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most other planets (retrograde rotation). On Venus, the sun rises in the west and sets in the east. It also rotates so slowly that its day is longer than its year.

fact: Cotton candy was originally 'Fairy Floss'
explanation: We know it as cotton candy, but when it was invented in 1897, it was called 'Fairy Floss'. It is still called Fairy Floss in Australia and 'Candy Floss' in the UK and other parts of the world.

fact: First mobile phone call was to a rival
explanation: On April 3, 1973, Motorola engineer Martin Cooper made the first public mobile phone call. He called Joel Engel, his rival at Bell Labs, essentially to brag that Motorola had beaten them to the invention.

fact: Bats always turn left out of a cave
explanation: It's a commonly cited fact that bats always turn left when exiting a cave. While not 100% true for every single bat species, for nearly all major colonies observed, the left-turn bias helps organize the chaotic exit and prevent mid-air collisions.

fact: Your stomach gets a new lining every 3 days
explanation: The hydrochloric acid in your stomach is strong enough to dissolve metal. To prevent it from digesting your own stomach, the mucous lining regenerates completely every 3 to 4 days.

fact: Pineapples were a status symbol
explanation: In 18th century England, pineapples were so rare and expensive that people didn't eat them. They rented them by the hour to carry around at parties as a symbol of extreme wealth and status.

fact: Owls don't have eyeballs
explanation: Owls have eye tubes. Their eyes are elongated and held in place by bone structures called sclerotic rings. Because they are tubes, owls cannot move their eyes in their sockets, which is why they have to turn their entire heads.

fact: YouTube started as a dating site
explanation: YouTube was originally launched on Valentine's Day 2005 as a video dating site called 'Tune In Hook Up'. The slogan was appeal to 'Tune In, Hook Up'. It failed, so the founders opened it up to any video uploads.

fact: Turkeys were worshipped as gods
explanation: The Mayan people believed turkeys were vessels of the gods and honored them with religious ceremonies. They were domesticated in Mexico long before they became the centerpiece of American Thanksgiving dinners.

fact: Cats can't taste sweet things
explanation: Cats are the only mammals that lack the taste receptor gene for sweetness. They are obligate carnivores, so they have no biological need to detect sugar. If your cat likes ice cream, it's for the fat, not the sugar.

fact: Hot water freezes faster than cold
explanation: Known as the Mpemba effect, hot water can freeze faster than cold water under certain specific conditions. Scientists are still debating the exact mechanism, citing evaporation, convection currents, and dissolved gases as possible causes.

fact: There are more trees on Earth than stars in the Milky Way
explanation: It sounds impossible, but estimates suggest there are about 3 trillion trees on Earth. By comparison, there are estimated to be between 100 and 400 billion stars in our Milky Way galaxy.

fact: Bitcoin's creator is a mystery
explanation: To this day, nobody knows the true identity of Satoshi Nakamoto, the person (or group) who invented Bitcoin in 2008. They hold roughly 1 million Bitcoins (worth billions) that have never been moved, making them a ghostly billionaire.

fact: The Titanic had a newspaper
explanation: The ship had its own daily newspaper called the 'Atlantic Daily Bulletin'. It was printed on board and featured news, stock prices, horse racing results, and society gossip received via the ship's wireless telegraph.

fact: Squirrels plant thousands of trees
explanation: Squirrels bury nuts to save them for winter, but they forget the location of millions of them every year. These forgotten nuts sprout into new trees, making squirrels one of the most important accidental environmentalists.

fact: Rats laugh when tickled
explanation: Scientists have discovered that rats emit high-pitched, ultrasonic chirps when they play or are tickled by researchers. These chirps are analogous to human laughter and indicate joy and social bonding.

fact: Lemons float, limes sink
explanation: Despite being similar fruits, lemons usually float in water while limes sink. This is because limes are denser than lemons, which have a thicker, porous skin that holds more air pockets.

fact: Oxford University is older than Aztecs
explanation: Teaching began at Oxford University as early as 1096. The Aztec Empire didn't originate until the founding of Tenochtitlan in 1325. This means Oxford was already educating students for over 200 years before the Aztecs built their empire.

fact: A computer was a person
explanation: Before the 20th century, a 'computer' was a job title. It referred to a human being (often a woman) whose job was to perform hours of repetitive calculations by hand for astronomy, navigation, or engineering.

fact: Catch-22 was originally Catch-18
explanation: Joseph Heller originally titled his book 'Catch-18'. However, just before publication, another war novel called 'Mila 18' was released. To avoid confusion, Heller changed the number to 22, creating the famous phrase we use today.

fact: Green Eggs and Ham was a bet
explanation: Dr. Seuss wrote 'Green Eggs and Ham' on a bet with his publisher, Bennett Cerf. Cerf bet him $50 that he couldn't write a book using only 50 distinct words. Seuss won the bet.

fact: Frankenstein is the doctor, not the monster
explanation: One of the most common literary errors is calling the creature 'Frankenstein'. Victor Frankenstein is the scientist who created him. The creature is never named in Mary Shelley's novel; he is referred to as 'monster', 'fiend', or 'it'.

fact: Space smells like steak
explanation: Astronauts returning from spacewalks consistently report a distinct odor clinging to their suits. They describe it as smelling like seared steak, hot metal, or welding fumes. This is likely caused by ozone and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

fact: Bees can recognize faces
explanation: Like crows, honey bees can be trained to recognize human faces. Despite having a tiny brain, they use a process called 'configural processing' to piece together the features of a face, similar to how primates do.

fact: Your bones are wet
explanation: We see skeletons as dry and white, but living bone is actually pink, wet, and flexible. It is a living tissue filled with blood vessels and cells. The dry white bones are just the leftover mineral structure after death.

fact: A 'jiffy' is a real unit of time
explanation: In physics, a 'jiffy' is the time it takes light to travel one centimeter in a vacuum (about 33.3564 picoseconds). In computer engineering, it is often 1/100th of a second. It's not just a slang term for 'quickly'.

fact: Santa's suit wasn't always red
explanation: Before the 1930s, Santa Claus was depicted in various colors, including blue, green, and tan. The modern image of the jolly man in a bright red suit was largely popularized (though not invented) by Coca-Cola advertisements.

fact: Carrots used to be purple
explanation: The original domesticated carrots from Afghanistan were purple or yellow. The orange carrot we know today was developed by Dutch growers in the 17th century, supposedly to honor the House of Orange, the Dutch royal family.

fact: Krakatoa's explosion was the loudest sound
explanation: The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa made the loudest sound in recorded history. It was heard 3,000 miles away (like hearing a sound in Dublin from New York). It ruptured the eardrums of sailors 40 miles away.

fact: Wombat poop is cubed (Confirmed)
explanation: Duplicate check: Reaffirming the unique cubic shape of wombat scat, caused by varying elasticity in the instestinal walls, preventing the poop from rolling off rocks.

fact: The shortest reign was 20 minutes
explanation: Louis XIX was King of France for just 20 minutes on August 2, 1830. He ascended the throne after his father abdicated, and then spent the next 20 minutes arguing before he too abdicated in favor of his nephew.

fact: Facebook is blue because of Zuckerberg
explanation: Mark Zuckerberg is red-green colorblind. Blue is the color he can see best. That is the primary reason why Facebook's color scheme has always been dominated by blue.

fact: Pringles are 42% potato
explanation: Because they are made from dehydrated potato flakes and flour rather than sliced potatoes, the FDA ruled that Pringles cannot be marketed as 'potato chips'. They must be labeled as 'potato crisps'.

fact: Some turtles breathe through their cloaca (Confirmed)
explanation: Duplicate check: Reaffirming cloacal respiration in turtles during hibernation, allowing them to extract oxygen from water through their rear end.

fact: Fingernails grow 4x faster than toenails
explanation: If you feel like you clip your fingers way more often than your toes, you're right. Fingernails grow about 3mm per month, while toenails grow only about 1mm per month, likely due to better blood flow in the hands.

fact: The guillotine was used until 1977
explanation: We associate the guillotine with the French Revolution (1700s), but France continued to use it as the official method of execution for centuries. The last beheading took place in September 1977, the same year Star Wars was released.

fact: Sunset on Mars is blue
explanation: On Earth, our atmosphere scatters blue light, making the sky blue during the day and red at sunset. On Mars, the dust in the atmosphere does the opposite, making the sky reddish during the day and the sunset a cool blue.

fact: Alaska was bought for 2 cents an acre
explanation: In 1867, the US purchased Alaska from Russia for $7.2 million. At the time, it was called 'Seward's Folly' because people thought it was a frozen wasteland. The price worked out to roughly 2 cents per acre.

fact: A blue whale's tongue weighs an elephant
explanation: The blue whale is the largest animal to ever exist. Its tongue alone can weigh as much as an entire female African elephant (about 2.7 metric tons), and its heart is the size of a small car.

fact: Twinkies don't last forever
explanation: It's an urban legend that Twinkies have an infinite shelf life and could survive a nuclear war. In reality, they have a shelf life of about 45 days (extended from the original 26) before they get stale and spoil.

fact: The Eiffel Tower grows in summer
explanation: Due to thermal expansion, the iron structure of the Eiffel Tower expands when it gets hot. In the summer, the tower can grow by up to 15 centimeters (6 inches). It also leans slightly away from the sun.

fact: Giraffes sleep 30 minutes a day
explanation: Giraffes have one of the shortest sleep requirements of any mammal. They sleep for only about 30 minutes a day, often in quick 5-minute power naps while standing up, to keep watch for predators.

fact: Humans are bioluminescent (Confirmed)
explanation: Duplicate check: Confirmed that humans emit a faint glow, strongest in the late afternoon around the face, but it is too weak for our eyes to see.

fact: Vikings didn't have horned helmets
explanation: There is no archaeological evidence that Vikings wore helmets with horns. That image comes from 19th-century opera costumes (Wagner's Ring Cycle). In battle, horns would have been a liability, giving enemies something to grab.

fact: Koala fingerprints confuse police
explanation: Koalas are the only non-primates with fingerprints. Their prints are so similar to humans (with arches, loops, and whorls) that they could theoretically taint heavy crime scenes in Australia.

fact: The footprints on the Moon will last forever
explanation: Because the Moon has no atmosphere, there represents no wind or rain to erode the surface. The footprints left by Apollo astronauts could remain pristine for millions of years, unless hit by a meteorite.

fact: The word 'orange' came before the color
explanation: Before the fruit arrived in Europe, the color was called 'yellow-red' (geoluhread). The word comes from the Sanskrit 'naranga'. We named the color after the fruit, not the fruit after the color.

fact: Charlie Chaplin entered a look-alike contest
explanation: A popular legend (with some historical backing) states that Charlie Chaplin once secretly entered a Charlie Chaplin look-alike contest in a theater. He didn't win. In fact, he reportedly came in 20th place.

fact: Slugs have 4 noses
explanation: A slug has two pairs of tentacles on its head. The upper pair holds its eyes (sensing light), while the lower pair contains its olfactory organs (noses) used for smelling and tasting the environment.

fact: Wombats are the heroes of fires
explanation: During the Australian bushfires, reports surfaced of wombats allowing other animals (like wallabies and echidnas) to shelter in their deep, fire-resistant burrows, effectively saving them from the flames.

fact: Nutella was invented during WWII
explanation: During World War II, cocoa was rationed and very expensive. An Italian pastry maker named Pietro Ferrero extended his chocolate supply by mixing it with hazelnuts, which were abundant. This paste (Gianduja) eventually became Nutella.

fact: The 'ok' sign is universal
explanation: While 'OK' (Oll Korrect) is one of the most recognized words on the planet, using the hand gesture can be dangerous. In Brazil, Turkey, and parts of the Mediterranean, the circle gesture is considered an offensive insult.

fact: Ostriches can run faster than horses
explanation: Male ostriches can sprint at speeds over 43 mph (70 km/h), which is faster than most racehorses. Their long legs can cover 10 to 16 feet in a single stride.

fact: The Sun makes sound
explanation: The Sun vibrates with pressure waves. If space carried sound, the Sun would be incredibly loud (about 100dB on Earth, like a chainsaw constantly running nearby). Thankfully, the vacuum of space protects our ears.

fact: Diamonds can burn
explanation: Diamonds are made of pure carbon. If you heat a diamond to about 763Â°C (1405Â°F) in the presence of oxygen, it will simply catch fire and vanish into carbon dioxide gas, leaving absolutely no ash behind.

fact: Julius Caesar was kidnapped by pirates
explanation: When he was 25, Caesar was kidnapped by Cilician pirates who demanded 20 talents of ransom. He laughed and told them he was worth at least 50. While captive, he wrote poetry and promised to crucify them. After his release, he returned with a fleet and did exactly that.

fact: The internet has a restart key
explanation: Seven people hold 7 physical keys to the internet. In the event of a catastrophic cyberattack on the DNS system, they can meet at a secure US base to combine their keys and restart the master root DNS servers.

fact: Ducks have waterproof feathers
explanation: Ducks have a gland near their tail called the uropygial gland that produces oil. They use their bills to spread this oil over their feathers (preening), making them completely waterproof so they stay dry and warm even while swimming.

fact: Ancient Egyptians loved board games
explanation: One of the most popular pastimes in Ancient Egypt was a game called 'Senet'. It dates back to 3100 BC. Tutankhamun was buried with four Senet boards to play in the afterlife.

fact: Your brain uses 20% of your energy
explanation: Although the brain represents only about 2% of your total body weight, it is a metabolic hog. It consumes about 20% of the oxygen and calories your body uses just to keep the neurons firing.

fact: Cold welding exists in space
explanation: If two pieces of the same type of metal touch in the vacuum of space, they will instantly bond and become one piece. This is because there is no oxygen layer (oxide) on the surface to keep the atoms separate.
